revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|1616|literature}}
This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1616'''.
==Events== *[[January 1]] – King [[James VI and I|James I of England]] attends the [[masque]] ''[[The Golden Age Restored]]'', a satire by [[Ben Jonson]] on fallen court favorite the [[Robert Carr, 1st Earl of Somerset|Earl of Somerset]]. The king asks for a repeat performance on January 4. *[[February 1]] – King James I of England grants [[Ben Jonson]] an annual pension of 100 [[Mark (money)|mark]]s, making him ''de facto'' [[Poet Laureate of the United Kingdom|poet laureate]].<ref>{{cite web|first=Ian|last=Donaldson|title=Jonson, Benjamin (1572–1637)|work=[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2004|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/15116|accessdate=2012-10-09|doi=10.1093/ref:odnb/15116}} {{ODNBsub}}</ref> *[[March 5]] – [[Nicolaus Copernicus]]' ''[[De revolutionibus orbium coelestium]]'' (1543) is placed on the ''[[Index Librorum Prohibitorum]]'' by the Roman Catholic Church. *[[March 19]] – Sir [[Walter Ralegh]], [[English people|English]] explorer of the [[New World]], is released from the [[Tower of London]], where he was imprisoned for treason and has been composing ''The Historie of the World'', in order to conduct a second (ill-fated) expedition in search of [[El Dorado]] in [[South America]].<ref name="Pocket On This Day">{{cite book|title=Penguin Pocket On This Day|publisher=Penguin Reference Library|isbn=0-14-102715-0|year=2006}}</ref> *[[April 22]] ([[Gregorian calendar]]) – [[Miguel de Cervantes]] dies (three days after completing ''[[Los Trabajos de Persiles y Sigismunda]]'') in Madrid and is buried the following day in the Trinitarias convent there. *[[April 23]] ([[Julian calendar]]) – [[William Shakespeare]] dies (on or about his 52nd birthday) in retirement in [[Stratford-upon-Avon]] and is buried two days later in the [[Church of the Holy Trinity, Stratford-upon-Avon|Church of the Holy Trinity]] there. *[[June 10]] – Foundation date of Ets Haim Library, housed from 1675 at the [[Portuguese Synagogue (Amsterdam)]]. *August – [[Christopher Beeston]] acquires the lease of the [[Cockpit Theatre|Cockpit]] off [[Drury Lane]] in London and converts it into a theatre.<ref>{{cite book|last=Wickham|authorlink=Glynne Wickham|first=Glynne|year=1972|title=Early English Stages 1300 to 1660, Vol. '''2''', 1576 to 1660, Part '''II'''|location=London|publisher=Routledge|page=117}}</ref> * October/November – [[Ben Jonson]]'s satirical five-act comedy ''[[The Devil is an Ass]]'' is produced at the [[Blackfriars Theatre]], London, by the [[King's Men (playing company)|King's Men]], poking fun at contemporary credence in witchcraft (published 1631). *[[November 6]]/[[November 25|25]] – [[Ben Jonson]]'s works are published in a collected [[Ben Jonson folios|folio]] edition; the first of any English playwright.<ref>{{cite book|last=Palmer|first=Alan|author2=Veronica|year=1992|title=The Chronology of British History|publisher=Century Ltd|location=London|pages= 170–172|isbn=0-7126-5616-2}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Bland|first=M.|title=William Stansby and the production of the ''Workes of Beniamin Jonson'', 1615–16|journal=The Library|publisher=[[Bibliographical Society]]|volume=20|year=1998|page=10|doi=10.1093/library/20.1.1}}</ref> *[[December 25]] – Ben Jonson's ''[[Christmas, His Masque]]'' is presented before King James I of England. * [[George Chapman]]'s translations of [[Homer]], previously issued in piecemeal fashion, are published complete for the first time, as ''The Whole Works of Homer'', the first full English-language edition. * Marie Venier, called Laporte, is the first actress to appear on the [[history of theater|stage]] in [[Paris]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Searles|first=Colbert|year=1925|title=Allusions to the Contemporary Theater of 1616 by Francois Osset|journal=[[Modern Language Notes]]|volume=40|issue=8|pages=481–483}}</ref>
==New books== <!-- (''Title of published book translation''), ("Title of published poem/story translation"), (Literal translation of title) --> ===Prose=== *[[Johannes Valentinus Andreae]] (claimed) – ''[[Chymical Wedding of Christian Rosenkreutz|Chymische Hochzeit Christiani Rosencreutz Anno 1459]]'' ("The Chymical Wedding of Christian Rosenkreutz") *[[Christoph Besold]] – ''Axiomata Philosophico-Theologica'' *Dr. [[John Bullokar]] – ''[[An English Expositor]]: teaching the interpretation of the hardest words used in our language, with sundry explications, descriptions and discourses'' (dictionary) *[[George Chapman]] (translator) – ''The Whole Works of Homer'' *[[Philipp Clüver]] – ''Germania Antiqua'' *Fray [[Martín de Murúa]] – ''{{lang|es|Historia General del Pirú}}'' *[[Francis de Sales]], [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Lausanne, Geneva and Fribourg|Roman Catholic Bishop of Geneva]] – ''Treatise on the Love of God'' *John Deacon – ''Tobacco Tortured in the Filthy Fumes of Tobacco Refined'' *[[Thomas Dekker (poet)|Thomas Dekker]] – ''The Artillery Garden'' *[[Robert Fludd]] – ''{{lang|la|Apologia Compendiaria, Fraternitatem de Rosea Cruce suspicionis}}'' *[[Johannes Gysius]] – ''{{lang|nl|Oorsprong en voortgang der Nederlandtscher beroerten}}'' (Origin and progress of the disturbances in the Netherlands)<ref name="WDL">{{cite web|url=http://www.wdl.org/en/item/515/|title=Mirror of the Cruel and Horrible Spanish Tyranny Perpetrated in the Netherlands, by the Tyrant, the Duke of Alba, and Other Commanders of King Philip II|website=[[World Digital Library]]|year=1620|accessdate=2013-08-25}}</ref> *[[Ben Jonson]] – ''The Workes of Beniamin Ionson'' ([[Ben Jonson folios|the first folio]] collection) *[[John Smith (explorer)|Captain John Smith]] – ''[[A Description of New England]]'' *[[Giulio Cesare Vanini]] – ''{{lang|la|De admirandis naturae reginae deaeque mortalium arcanis}}''
===Drama=== *Anonymous – ''The Barriers'' *[[Francis Beaumont]] and [[John Fletcher (playwright)|John Fletcher]] – ''[[The Scornful Lady]]'' published *[[Gerbrand Adriaensz Bredero]] – ''Treur-spel van Rodd'rick ende Alphonsus''; ''Griane''; ''Lucelle'' *[[Pieter Corneliszoon Hooft]] – ''Warenar'' *[[Ben Jonson]] **''[[The Golden Age Restored]]'' **''[[The Devil is an Ass]]'' **''[[Christmas, His Masque]]'' *[[Christopher Marlowe]] (posthumous) – ''[[The Tragical History of Doctor Faustus|Doctor Faustus]]'' (third quarto – the "B text"; original text probably written around 1589) *[[Thomas Middleton]] – ''[[The Witch (play)|The Witch]]'' (latest probable date)<ref>{{cite book|editor1=Logan, Terence P. |editor2=Smith, Denzell S. |title=The Popular School: A Survey and Bibliography of Recent Studies in English Renaissance Drama|location=Lincoln|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|year=1975|page=69}}</ref> *[[Anthony Munday]] – ''Chrysanaleia''
===Poetry=== {{main|1616 in poetry}} *[[Agrippa d'Aubigné]] – ''Les Tragiques'' *[[George Chapman]] – ''The Whole Works of Homer'' (first publication of full English translation)<ref>Date evidence, etc. [http://www.jarndyce.co.uk/online_catalogues/E-LIST1585-1752.pdf Retrieved 12 September 2017.]</ref> *[[Ben Jonson]] – "[[To Celia]]" and "On my first Sonne"
==Births== *[[March 24]] – [[John Birkenhead]], English political writer and journalist (died [[1679 in literature|1679]]) *[[April 27]] – [[Jeremias Felbinger]], German Socinian writer (died c. 1690) *[[October 11]] – [[Andreas Gryphius]], [[Silesia]]n poet and dramatist (died [[1664 in literature|1664]]) *[[October 16]] – [[Nicholas Culpeper]], English herbalist, physician and astrologer (died [[1664 in literature|1664]]) *[[November 17]] ''(baptized)'' – [[William Gurnall]], English writer and cleric (died [[1679 in literature|1679]]) *[[December 17]] – [[Roger L'Estrange]], English pamphleteer (died [[1704 in literature|1704]]) *''Unknown date'' – [[John Owen (theologian)|John Owen]], English theologian (died [[1683 in literature|1683]]) [[File:Shakespeare's grave epitaph.JPG|thumb|350px|Shakespeare's gravestone]]
==Deaths== *[[January 6]] – [[Philip Henslowe]], English theatre impresario (born [[1550 in literature|1550]]) *[[February 13]] – [[Anders Sørensen Vedel]], Danish historian (born [[1542 in literature|1542]]) *[[March 6]] – [[Francis Beaumont]], English dramatist (born [[1584 in literature|1584]]) *[[April 22]] (Gregorian calendar) – [[Miguel de Cervantes]], Spanish novelist (born [[1547 in literature|1547]]) *[[April 23]] (Julian calendar) – [[William Shakespeare]], English dramatist and poet (born [[1564 in literature|1564]]) *[[April 23]] (Gregorian calendar) – [[Garcilaso de la Vega (chronicler)|Garcilaso de la Vega]], Peruvian Spanish chronicler (born [[1539 in literature|1539]]) *[[August 7]] – [[Vincenzo Scamozzi]], Venetian writer on architecture (born [[1548 in literature|1548]]) *[[November 23]] – [[Richard Hakluyt]], English travel writer (born [[1552 in literature|1552]])
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1616 books| ]] [[Category:Years in literature]] [[Category:Years of the 17th century in literature]]

{{Year nav topic5|1638|music}}
The year '''1638 in [[music]]''' involved some significant events.
== Events == *[[February 6]] – ''[[Luminalia]]'', a [[masque]] written by Sir [[William Davenant]] and designed by [[Inigo Jones]], is staged at the English Court. The work features music by [[Nicholas Lanier]].
== Publications == *[[Claudio Monteverdi]] – ''Madrigali guerrieri, et amorosi con alcuni opuscoli in genere rappresentativo, che saranno per brevi Episodij fra i canti senza gesto. Libro ottavo di Claudio Monteverde Maestro di Capella della Serenissima Republica di Venetia'' (eighth book of [[Madrigal (music)|madrigals]] ''a''5), published in [[Venice]]
== Classical music == *Nicolas Formé – ''Ecce tu pulchra es'', a double choir motet
== [[Opera]] == *[[Benedetto Ferrari]] and [[Francesco Manelli]] – ''La maga fulminata'', premiéred at [[Teatro San Cassiano]], in [[Venice]] *[[Michelangelo Rossi]] – ''Andromeda'', premiered in [[Ferrara]].
== Births == *[[July 15]] – [[Giovanni Buonaventura Viviani]], Italian composer and violinist (d. c. 1693) *''date unknown'' – [[Diogo Dias Melgás]], composer (died 1700)
== Deaths == *[[January 21]] – [[Ignazio Donati]], composer (born c.1570) *[[May 27]] – [[Nicolas Formé]], French composer (born 1567) *September – [[John Wilbye]], composer (born 1574) *[[November 6]] – [[Gabriel Díaz Bessón]], composer (born 1590) *''date unknown'' – [[Francis Pilkington]], composer, lutenist and singer (born c.1565) *''probable'' – [[Settimia Caccini]], composer and singer (born 1591)
[[Category:1638 in music| ]] [[Category:17th century in music]] [[Category:Years in music]]

[[File:Alcoa Aluminum advert 1953.png|thumb|The image used in the advertisement]] In 1953 [[Alcoa Inc|Alcoa Aluminum]]<ref name="tele" /> produced an advertisement promoting their HyTop twist-off [[bottle cap]]. The advertisement, often erroneously attributed to [[Del Monte Foods]],<ref name=ny>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv/sexist-ads-mad-men-era-gallery-1.1050013?pmSlide=1.1050003 |title=Del Monte Ketchup: 'You mean a woman can open it?' 'Mad Men' premiere: Sexist ads from the era of Don Draper |work=New York Daily News |date= |accessdate=2017-01-09}}</ref> featured a picture of a woman with the tagline "you mean a woman can open it?"<ref name=tele>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/goodlife/living/beyond-belief-shocking-vintage-adverts-from-the-golden-age/alcoa-aluminium/ |title=Alcoa Aluminium - Beyond Belief: Shocking vintage adverts from the 'Golden Age' |work=Telegraph |date= |accessdate=2017-01-09}}</ref> The advertisement has been subject to criticism in later reviews and is viewed as a symbol of casual [[sexism]] in the United States in the 1950s.<ref name=mm>{{cite web|author=Advertising |url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/26-sexist-ads-of-the-mad-men-era-2014-5/#51-show-her-its-a-mans-world-2 |title=26 Sexist Ads Of The Mad Men Era |work=Business Insider |date=2014-05-08 |accessdate=2017-01-09}}</ref>
== Description == The advertisement features a woman wearing red lipstick and looking at the reader while holding a Del Monte ketchup bottle with the appearance of being about to open it. The tagline directly below it is, "You mean a woman can open it?" with the word ''woman'' underlined. The first sentence of the article it accompanied stated, "Easily—without a knife blade, a bottle opener, or even a husband!"<ref name=od>{{cite web|url=https://www.theodysseyonline.com/why-we-cant-afford-not-to-be-politically-correct |title=Why We Can't Afford Not To Be Politically Correct |work=The Odyssey |date=2016-10-17 |accessdate=2017-01-09}}</ref>
== Critical review == The advertisement has been described as an example of targeted advertising towards women,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slideshare.net/aridinger/postwwii-advertisements |title=Aprons in Advertising |publisher=Slideshare |date= |accessdate=2017-01-09}}</ref> is viewed as a symbol of [[social stereotype]]s during the 1950s<ref>{{cite book | first =Elizabeth | last =Muir | title =Canadian Women in the Sky: 100 Years of Flight | publisher = Dundurn | edition = | year = 2015 | isbn = 1459731883 | page = 138}}</ref>, and is frequently cited as emblematic of the ''[[Mad Men]]'' era.<ref name=mm /><ref name=ind /><ref>{{cite web|last=Wicks |first=Heidi |url=http://theindependent.ca/tag/mad-men/ |title=Mad Men |work=The Independent.ca |date=2011-04-14 |accessdate=2017-01-09}}</ref> Scholarly interpretation states that it implies that a woman is dependent upon her husband to do things for her.<ref name=od /> In one such commentary, the ''[[New York Daily News]]'' stated that the woman in the advertisement is "clearly stunned and possibly delighted" at being able to open the bottle easily.<ref name=ny /> In addition, the advertisement has been used as a symbol of retro advertising, with a book bearing the same title as the tagline being published in 2000 by [[Adams Media]] detailing retro advertisements.<ref>{{cite book|author=Ad Nauseum |title=You Mean a Woman Can Open It...? |publisher=Adams Media |year=2000 |isbn=1580623778 }}</ref> It has been claimed that it enforced the stereotype of a woman as an unintelligent housewife.<ref name=ind>{{cite web|first=Susie |last=Rushden |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/columnists/susie-rushton-turn-the-heating-off-ndash-and-feel-virtuous-2146961.html |title=Turn the heating off – and feel virtuous |work=The Independent |date=2010-11-30 |accessdate=2017-01-09}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:1953 documents]] [[Category:1953 in the United States|Alcoa Aluminum advertisement]] [[Category:Advertisements]] [[Category:Alcoa]] [[Category:Sexism]] [[Category:Stereotypes of women]] [[Category:Women in art]]

revision.comment: Added "Aboriginal Current Affairs" as a distinct program category
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox Radio station |name = Kool N Deadly (3KND) |image = 3kndlogo.jpg |area = Melbourne, Australia |branding = 3KND |frequency = 1503 kHz AM |airdate = June 2003 |format = Indigenous Issues & Music |language = English / First Languages |power = 5 kW pY |owner = South East Indigenous Media Ass'n Inc |website = {{URL|www.3knd.org.au}} }}
'''3KND''' is a [[community radio]] station which represents the [[Indigenous Australian|Indigenous]] communities within Greater [[Melbourne]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], [[Australia]].<ref name='3KND vision 2007-09-05'>{{cite web | url = http://www.3knd.org.au/vision.htm | title = Vision | accessdate = 2007-09-05 | work = 3KND | publisher = SEIMA Executive Board | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070829221148/http://3knd.org.au/vision.htm | archivedate = 2007-08-29 }}</ref> 3KND broadcasts in Melbourne at 1503 on the AM radio band<ref name='CBOnline 3KND 2007-09-05'>{{cite web |url=http://www.cbonline.org.au/index.cfm?pageId=13,11,6,3223 |title=3KND - Kool and Deadly |accessdate=2007-09-05 |work=CBOnline |publisher=Community Broadcasting Foundation |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070903074850/http://www.cbonline.org.au/index.cfm?pageId=13%2C11%2C6%2C3223 |archivedate=3 September 2007 |deadurl=no }}</ref> and also streams on the internet.<ref name='3KND streaming 2007-09-05'>{{ cite web | url=http://www.3knd.org.au/streaming.htm | title=Live Streaming |accessdate=2007-09-05 |work=3KND | publisher=SEIMA Executive Board |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070829220551/http://3knd.org.au/streaming.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-08-29}}</ref> As at late 2006, 3KND has the beginnings of an mp3 library.<ref name='3KND podcasts 2007-09-05'>{{ cite web |url=http://www.3knd.org.au/podcasts.htm |title=Podcasts |accessdate=2007-09-05 |work=3KND |publisher=SEIMA Executive Board |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070829220808/http://3knd.org.au/podcasts.htm |archivedate=29 August 2007 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> The South Eastern Indigenous Media Association is the station operator.<ref name='3KND profile 2007-09-05'>{{ cite web |url=http://www.3knd.org.au/profile.htm |title=Profile |accessdate=2007-09-05 |work=3KND |publisher=SEIMA Executive Board |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070829220928/http://3knd.org.au/profile.htm |archivedate=29 August 2007 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> The station provides training for indigenous broadcasters.<ref name='CBOnline Melb 1st 2007-09-05'>{{ cite web |first= |last=NIRS |coauthors= |title=3KND - Melbourne's First Indigenous Radio Station |date=2004-10-26 |publisher=Community Broadcasting Foundation |url=http://www.cbonline.org.au/index.cfm?pageId=43,127,3,739 |work=CBOnline |pages= |accessdate=2007-09-05 |language= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070830053246/http://www.cbonline.org.au/index.cfm?pageId=43%2C127%2C3%2C739 |archivedate=30 August 2007 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
==History== The 1503 frequency had been previously vacated by [[3AK]] as it moved to occupy 1116 AM<ref name='age.com.au Radio Daze'>{{cite web | first = Brett | last = de Hoedt | coauthors = | title = Radio Daze | date = 2003-06-08 | publisher = Fairfax | url = http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/06/07/1054700443908.html | work = The Age | pages = | accessdate = 2007-09-05 | language = }}</ref> The first test broadcast was in 1998.<ref name='3KND profile 2007-09-05'/>
3KND was one of the later entrants into the temporary community broadcasting period in Melbourne as part of the lead up to the granting of four additional community licences for the City. It was granted the only AM license available for community radio at that time. 3KND was licensed at the same time as [[JOY 94.9]], for the [[LGBT]] community; [[Christian contemporary]]-formatted [[Light FM|Triple 7]] (now LightFM); and the student-run [[SYN Media#Radio|SYN FM]] (now SYN 90.7)<ref name='acma.gov.au NR107/2001'>{{cite media release |title=SYN FM, Triple Seven, SEIMA and Joy to get Melbourne community radio licences |date=2001-12-19 |publisher=Australian Communications and Media Authority |url=http://www.acma.gov.au/WEB/STANDARD/1001/pc=PC_91122 |work=Media release archive |pages= |accessdate=2007-09-05 |language= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071007165722/http://www.acma.gov.au/WEB/STANDARD/1001/pc%3DPC_91122 |archivedate=7 October 2007 |deadurl=no }}</ref> At the time it was founded, 3KND was Melbourne's first Indigenous radio station.<ref name='CBOnline Melb 1st 2007-09-05'/>
Official broadcasting began in June 2003.<ref name='CBOnline 3KND 2007-09-05'/> Internet streaming was introduced in 2006. The launch of 3KND on digital radio in 2010.
==Internet streaming== 3KND's internet streaming is provided <!-- in [[HE-AAC|aacPlus]] format. Suitable client software for the [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] platform includes: [[Winamp]] Lite, [[foobar2000]], [[MPlayer]] and [[Windows Media Player]] versions 6.4, 7.0, 7.1, 8.0, 9.0, 10.0, 11.0 (with the [http://www.orban.com/plugin/ Orban aacPlus plugin]),<ref name='orban.com aacPlus'>{{ cite web |url=http://www.orban.com/plugin/ |title= Orban/Coding Technologies AAC/aacPlus Player Plugin | accessdate=2007-09-05 | work = Orban | publisher = Orban CRL }}</ref> For the [[Macintosh|Mac]] and other [[Linux|GNU/Linux]] and [[Berkeley Software Distribution|BSD]] platforms suitable client software includes [[MPlayer]] and [[VLC media player]]. The stream is provided at two bit rates: 20 kbit/s and 48 kbit/s.<ref name='3KND streaming 2007-09-05'>{{cite web | url = http://www.3knd.org.au/streaming.htm | title = Live Streaming | accessdate = 2007-09-05 | work = 3KND | publisher = SEIMA Executive Board | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070829220551/http://3knd.org.au/streaming.htm | archivedate = 2007-08-29 }}</ref> --> by [[Internode (ISP)]].<ref name= m3u-from-internode >{{ cite web |url = http://media.on.net/radio/76.m3u |title=3KND streaming m3u |publisher = Internode | accessdate =2010-10-19}}</ref>
==Program categories== <ref name='3KND programs 2007-09-05'>{{cite web |url=http://www.3knd.org.au/programs.htm |title=Programs |accessdate=2007-09-05 |work=3KND |publisher=SEIMA Executive Board |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070829221426/http://3knd.org.au/programs.htm |archivedate=29 August 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> * Breakfast * Talkback & Chat * Aboriginal Current Affairs * Sports * Music and Entertainment * Arts News * Health Programs
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.3knd.org.au/ 3KND Official Website]
{{Melbourne AM}} {{Coord|37.7415|S|145.0023|E|type:landmark_region:AU-VIC|display=title}}

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Christ in the Garden of Gethsemane]]; added [[Category:Christ in the Garden of Gethsemane in art]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:The Agony in the Garden William Blake.jpg|thumb|400px|''The Agony in the Garden'', 1799–1800. [[Tempera]] on tinned iron, 27 cm × 38 cm]] '''''The Agony in the Garden''''' is a small painting by [[William Blake]], completed as part of his 1799–1800 series of Bible illustrations commissioned by his patron and friend Thomas Butts. The work illustrates a passage from the [[Gospel of Luke]] which describes [[Agony in the Garden|Christ's turmoil]] in the [[Gethsemane|Garden of Gethsemane]] before his arrest and Crucifixion following [[Judas Iscariot|Judas]]'s betrayal.<ref name="h64">Hamlyn et al, 64</ref> In Blake's painting a brilliantly coloured and majestic angel breaks through the surrounding darkness and descends from a cloud to aid and physically support Jesus in his hour of agony.<ref name="r123">Raine, 123</ref> The work is dominated by vertical lines, formed both from the trees and from the two arms of the angel. Two inner lines converge on Christ's palms, evoking the nails driven through him during his crucifixion.
''The Agony in the Garden'' was bequeathed by Blake collector Graham Robertson to the National Trust in 1948. It was acquired by the [[Tate|Tate Gallery]] the following year.<ref>[http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/blake-the-agony-in-the-garden-n05894 ''The Agony in the Garden'' c. 1799–1800]. [[Tate Britain]], London. Retrieved 14 September 2013.</ref>
==Description== Between 1799 and 1803, Blake produced over 150 biblical illustrations for Thomas Butts. Around 50 were complete for the 1799–1880 series, of which around 30 are extant. They are all around the same size; all but two are significantly larger than the average 28cm x 38cm. Only the present work is on tinned steel; the majority of the others are painted on canvas. The works, all minutely detailed and richly coloured, involve complex and innovative arrangement and design.<ref name="T112">Townsend et al, 112</ref>
The text accompanying ''The Agony in the Garden'' reads: "And there appeared an angel unto him from heaven, strengthening him. And being in an agony he prayed more earnestly, and his sweat was as it were great drops of blood falling down to the ground."<ref name="h64" /> The painting shows Christ kneeling in the garden with his arms outstretched and leaning backwards as if about to faint. He is held at the waist by an angel descending from a multi-coloured cloud. The angel supports Christ as he leans back, crying out in agony.<ref name="r123" /> Both the angel and cloud are composed by a dominant impasted white, and lined with brilliant varieties of red, blue, yellow and green pigments. Three vaguely described, almost ghostly, disciples kneel in the dark trees to either side.
[[File:Nativity by Blake.jpg|thumb|''Nativity'', 1790-1800. Tempera on copper. [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]].]] Art historian [[Anthony Blunt]] linked this work to Blake's ''Nativity'' and ''Procession to Calvary'', and contended that they provide insight to Blake's mindset at the time. The artist had earlier been preoccupied with the nature of evil and the duality of human nature, but seemingly emerged and found hope through the ideal of salvation through Christ. According to Blunt, Blake conveys this through the motif of a bright light shining into the darkness of mankind. In the present work this is perhaps expressed through the angel appearing in brilliantly illuminated colours from the darkness and foreboding of the trees.<ref>Keynes, Geoffrey. "'The Art of William Blake' by Anthony Blunt". ''Criticism'', Volume 2, No. 3, 1960.</ref>
The work is built up from a number of layers of paint above the underlying priming. In some cases the layers are separated by films of binding glue. The foreground is built from a chalk ground above the priming, which gives added texture, and is especially evident around the areas of the tress and scrubs.<ref name="T120">Townsend et al, 120-121</ref>
==Material== [[File:Eve Tempted by the Serpent William Blake.jpg|thumb|left|320px|''Eve Tempted by the Serpent''. Tempera on Copper. Another work from the series painted on metal, in this case copperplate.]] The painting is unique in Blake's oeuvre in that the [[tempera]] is painted on tinned iron. Most of the works in the series were painted onto canvas, with three on copper and only the present work on tinned iron. It has been suggested that this plate may originally have formed the lid of a box, possibly a paint box.<ref>Stoner, 103</ref> The work is further unique in that he employed cherry gum in his mixture, utilising a blend more commonly associated with earlier, medieval [[illuminated manuscripts]], but which delivers a smoother and more durable effect.<ref name="t120">Townsend et al, 120</ref>
In employing tinned iron Blake was likely experimenting with methods of etching or painting on metal, perhaps following the examples of [[Lucas van Leyden]] and [[Albrecht Dürer]]'s work on [[Intaglio printing|copperplate]].<ref name="t30">Townsend et al, 29–30</ref> The surface was prepared with oil and lead before the application of the paint, although red lead pigment was applied directly onto the tin around the area of the angel's lower back and waist. Unfortunately this pigment is not well bound to the surface and has suffered damage and loss of paint.<ref name="m87">Mulhallen, 87</ref>
Some areas of colour were retouched by restorers around 1850 following dulling and loss of paint. This is most obvious with the bright greens to either side of Christ. However, the additions are barely noticeable as the restorers employed pigments prepared in a similar matter to the originals.<ref name="t157">Townsend et al, 157</ref>
==Condition== ''The Agony in the Garden'' is in very poor condition. This is mainly due to a built up of material following corrosion of the iron.<ref name="t30" /> This material has gathered between the painting's metal surface and priming, resulting in the delamination and displacement of pigment.<ref name="t155">Townsend et al, 155</ref> Ironically, Blake sealed his metal support with red paint bound with a gum mixture and animal glue, which was at the time thought of as a corrosion inhibitor. But these surfaces offered little protection against the decay of the paint layers, and in fact contributed to the displacement of pigment.<ref name="t119">Townsend et al, 119</ref>
There is a damaged signature "WBinv" in white paint at the lower right, although it is undated.<ref name="t118">Townsend et al, 118</ref>

{{infobox saint | honorific_prefix = Saint | name = Ailerán | death_date = 29 December 664 | feast_day = 29 December | major_works = ''Ancestry of Our Lord Jesus Christ'' | residence = [[Ireland]] }}
'''Ailerán''', also known as '''Ailerán sapientis''' (Ailerán the Wise) was an [[Irish people|Irish]] [[scholar]] and [[saint]] who died on 29 December, 664 or 665. His [[feast day]] is December 29.
==Biography== Ailerán was one of the most distinguished scholars at the School of [[Clonard Abbey|Clonard]] in the 7th century.<ref name=grattan>Grattan-Flood, William. "St. Aileran." The Catholic Encyclopedia. Vol. 1. New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1907. 20 Sept. 2012 [http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/01234c.htm]</ref>
His early life is not recorded, but he was attracted to Clonard by the fame of Saint [[Finnian of Clonard|Finnián]] and his disciples. He became [[Reader (liturgy)|lector]] of the school<ref>[http://www.fourcourtspress.ie/product.php?intProductID=134 Ailerani Interpretatio Mystica Progenitorum Domini Iesu Christi] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406132134/http://www.fourcourtspress.ie/product.php?intProductID=134 |date=2012-04-06 }}</ref> in 650. He died of the [[Yellow Plague]], and his death is recorded in the [[Annals of Ulster]].<ref>[http://brigid-undertheoak.blogspot.com/2010/01/irish-saints-of-december-aireran-wise.html Aileran]</ref> Because of his knowledge of the works of [[Origen]], [[Philo]], [[St. Jerome]], [[Augustine of Hippo|St. Augustine]], and others, he was well versed in patristic literature.
==Works==
According to [[John Colgan]], numerous works can be ascribed to Ailerán, including the ''Fourth Life of [[Saint Patrick]]'', a Latin litany, and the ''Lives'' of [[Saint Brigid]] and Saint [[Féichín of Fore]]. Ailerán's best known work is his mystical interpretation of the ''Ancestry of Our Lord Jesus Christ'', according to the [[genealogy of Jesus]] in [[Gospel of Matthew|Saint Matthew's Gospel]].<ref name=grattan/> This was published in the [[Benedictine]] edition of the [[Church Fathers|Fathers]], and the editors said that they published it although Aileran was not a Benedictine, because he " unfoulded the meaning of the Sacred Scripture with so much learning and ingenuity that every student of the Sacred Volume and especially preachers of the Divine Word will regard the publication as most acceptable."<ref>[http://www.libraryireland.com/WestCorkHistory/Monasteries.php Monasticism in Ireland]</ref> Another work of his is titled ''A Short Moral Explanation of the Sacred Names'', which could be a fragment of a larger work.

{{Infobox comics creator | name = Ardian Syaf | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Tulungagung]], [[East Java]], [[Indonesia]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Indonesian | pencil = y | alias = | signature = | notable works = ''[[Batgirl]]'', ''[[Brightest Day]]'' and ''[[Welcome to the Jungle (comics)|Welcome to the Jungle]]'' | awards = Nominee for [[Hugo Award for Best Graphic Story]] in 2009 (for ''Welcome to the Jungle'')
Nominee for Hugo Award for Best Graphic Story in 2010 ''[[Captain Britain and MI13]] Volume 3: Vampire State'' | subcat = }} '''Ardian Syaf''' is an [[Indonesians|Indonesian]] [[comic book]] artist. He has worked for [[DC Comics]],{{cite web |url=http://www.dccomics.com/talent/ardian-syaf |title=Ardian Syaf|publisher=DC Comics|year=2013 |accessdate=6 November 2013}} [[Marvel Comics]], and [[Dynamite Entertainment]]. In April 2017 he became embroiled in controversy for inserting hidden anti-semitic and anti-Christian messages in ''[[X-Men Gold]]'' #1, for which his contract with Marvel Comics was terminated.Brown, Tracy (11 April 2017). [http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/la-et-entertainment-news-updates-april-marvel-officially-terminates-x-men-1491945410-htmlstory.html "'My career is over now': Marvel terminates 'X-Men Gold' artist's contract amid controversy"]. ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/article/39576705/marvel-fires-artist-ardian-syaf-over-religious-references-in-x-men-comic-book|title=Marvel fires artist Ardian Syaf over religious references in X-Men comic book|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=11 April 2017}} ==Early life== Ardian Syaf was born in [[Tulungagung]], [[East Java]], [[Indonesia]].Khoiri, Agniya (10 April 2017). [http://www.cnnindonesia.com/hiburan/20170410114154-241-206251/ardian-syaf-komikus-tulungagung-pemikat-dc-comics-dan-marvel/ "Ardian Syaf, Komikus Tulungagung Pemikat DC Comics dan Marvel"]. [[CNN Indonesia]]. He first developed the desire to draw [[comics]] in his youth, after his father bought him his first comic. Among his influences are [[Hermann Huppen]], a Belgian comics artist for whom Syaf has expressed admiration. He embarked upon a career as a professional [[comics artist]] in 2003, deciding that leaving his interest in drawing comics and working in a conventional job was not something he was willing to do.{{cite web |url=http://www.comicswaitingroom.com/dresdenfiles.html |title=Dresden File Interview |first=Avril |last=Brown |work=ComicsWaitingRoom.com |date=2008 |accessdate=11 April 2017}} ==Career== Syaf started his career in 2007 with [[Dabel Brothers Publishing]], illustrating ''[[The Dresden Files]]'' for 11 issues. Syaf's work on the 2008 graphic novel ''[[Welcome to the Jungle (comics)|Welcome to the Jungle]]'' was nominated for the 2008 [[Hugo Award for Best Graphic Story]], losing to ''[[Girl Genius]]''.[http://www.thehugoawards.org/hugo-history/2009-hugo-awards/ "2009 Hugo Awards"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090830061036/http://www.thehugoawards.org/hugo-history/2009-hugo-awards |date=2009-08-30 }}. [[The Hugo Awards]]. Retrieved 13 April 2017. ''Take a Chance'', written by novelist [[C. E. Murphy]] was published after that,Ferguson, David (October 3, 2016). [http://www.irishcomicnews.com/2016/10/take-chance-available-order-today/ "Take A Chance Available to Order From Today"]. Irish Comic News. although it had been written and drawn first.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} Syaf later signed to the Spanish agency, Utopia Studio.Lam, Steve (2015). [http://bamsmackpow.com/2015/02/10/superman-earth-one-volume-3-interview-with-artist-ardian-syaf/ "Superman: Earth One Volume 3 – Interview With Artist Ardian Syaf"]. Bam! Smack! Pow! At one point Syaf met an Irish screenwriter named Catie through Dabel Brothers, through which began to get work with [[Marvel Comics]], his earliest book assignments involving the sharing of penciling duties with other artists, such as Jorge Molina on ''[[X-Men: Manifest Destiny: Nightcrawler]]'' #1 (May 2009), and [[Leonard Kirk]] on ''[[Captain Britain and MI13]]'' #13 and 14 (July, August 2009). His earliest work for [[DC Comics]] was "[[The Origin of Congorilla]]" a backup story written by [[Len Wein]] that appeared in ''[[Justice League: Cry for Justice]]'' #1 (September 2009). He shared the art duties on ''[[Justice League of America]]'' (Vol. 2) #34 (August 2009) with [[Eddy Barrows]], but its quality was decried by critics.[http://comicbookroundup.com/comic-books/reviews/dc-comics/justice-league-of-america/34 "Justice League of America #34"]. Comic Book Roundup.Zawisza, Doug (24 June 2009). [http://www.cbr.com/justice-league-of-america-34/ "Justice League of America #34"]. [[CBR.com]]. In 2009, he signed a two-year exclusivity contract with DC. That contract ended in September 2011, though he indicated that it would be renewed, and that he would be drawing the ''[[Batgirl]]'' series as part of the company's 2011 reboot of its books, [[The New 52]],{{cite web |url= http://singaporecomix.blogspot.co.uk/2011/08/interview-with-ardian-syafstgcc-2011.html |title=Interview with Ardian Syaff at STGCC|first=Cheng |last=Tju|work=Singapore Comix|date=22 August 2011|accessdate=6 November 2013}}Cohen, Jason (26 June 2009). [http://www.comicsbulletin.com/reviews/124602675289293.htm "Justice League of America #34"]. [[Comics Bulletin]]. working with writer [[Gail Simone]]. During his run on that series, Simone set one storyline in an [[Indonesia]]n neighborhood of [[Gotham City]] in order to exploit Syaf's experience.[[Johnston, Rich]] (12 April 2017). [https://www.bleedingcool.com/2017/04/12/gail-simone-batgirl-artistic-collaborator-ardian-syaf/ "Gail Simone On Her Batgirl Artistic Collaborator, Ardian Syaf"]. Bleeding Cool. Syaf drew eight of that series' first nine issues, receiving generally positive reviews from critics.Esposito, Joey (7 September 2011). [http://www.ign.com/articles/2011/09/07/batgirl-1-review "Batgirl #1 Review"]. [[IGN]].Norris, Erik (12 October 2011). [http://www.ign.com/articles/2011/10/12/batgirl-2-review "Batgirl #2 Review"]. IGN.Elfring, Mat (9 November 2011). [https://comicvine.gamespot.com/reviews/batgirl-3/1900-335/ "Batgirl #3 – A Breath of Broken Glass Review"]. ComicVine.Nguyen, Minhquan (12 December 2011). [http://weeklycomicbookreview.com/2011/12/17/batgirl-4-review-2/ "Batgirl #4 – Review"]. [[Weekly Comic Book Review]]. His artwork for the premiere issue in particular drew praise by Iann Robinson of [[CraveOnline]] for the manner in which Syaf adapted his style during different parts of the story, effecting a "light and airy" during the daytime scenes with Barbara Gordon, a darker, shadowy look for in-costume scenes, and a grainy, old-fashioned cinematic appearance for the flashbacks.Robinson, Iann (8 September 2011). [http://www.craveonline.com/site/173920-new-52-review-batgirl-1 "New 52 Review: Batgirl #1"]. [[CraveOnline]]. When asked in a 2011 interview what projects he would like to work on, Syaf responded that he would like to draw [[Wolverine (comic book)|Wolverine]], as that is a character that he adores. He also stated that he would like to do a ''[[Tomb Raider]]'' story set in Indonesia, which would involve the superstitious beliefs of his home country. ===Easter egg references and ''X-Men Gold'' controversy=== Syaf is known to engage in the practice of hiding [[Easter egg (media)|Easter egg]] references to political figures in the backgrounds of his artwork. In ''[[Batgirl]]'' (Vol 4) #9 (July 2012), for example, Syaf included a storefront sign that referenced the [[President of Indonesia]], [[Joko Widodo]], although the text that accompanies the image of Widodo in Syaf's penciled artwork is covered by a caption in the final, published issue.Johnston, Rich (April 8, 2017). [https://www.bleedingcool.com/2017/04/08/marvel-artist-ardian-syaf-hid-anti-christian-jewish-messages-weeks-x-men-comic/ "Marvel Artist Ardian Syaf Hid Anti-Christian And Jewish Messages In This Week's X-Men Comic"]. [[Bleeding Cool]].[[Simone, Gail]] (w), Syaf, Ardian (p), Cifuentes, Vicente (i). "In the Line of Fire". ''[[Batgirl]]'' (Vol. 4) #9 (July 2012). [[DC Comics]]. In April 2017, Syaf was at the center of controversy for including multiple Easter eggs in ''[[X-Men Gold]]'' #1 that referenced the [[November 2016 Jakarta protests]] against [[Basuki Tjahaja Purnama]], the governor of Jakarta, which were viewed by readers as [[anti-Semitic]] and [[anti-Christian]]. Being both [[Overseas Chinese|ethnically Chinese]] and Christian in the Muslim-dominated Indonesia, where Christians and Chinese are still victims of racism and discrimination, and only the second Chinese Christian governor of Jakarta since 1965,{{cite news|author=Cochrane, Joe|title=An Ethnic Chinese Christian, Breaking Barriers in Indonesia|date=22 November 2014|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/23/world/asia/an-ethnic-chinese-christian-breaking-barriers-in-indonesia.html}}Harfenist, Ethan (August 17, 2014). [https://news.vice.com/article/jakarta-could-be-getting-its-first-ethnically-chinese-governor "Jakarta Could Be Getting Its First Ethnically Chinese Governor"]. [[Vice News]]. Basuki had been the target of racism by [[Islamist]] hardliners.{{cite web|title=The Leaderboard: Basuki "Ahok" Tjahaja Purnama|date=November 27, 2012|url=http://cogitasia.com/the-leaderboard-basuki-ahok-tjahaja-purnama/|publisher=[[Center for Strategic & International Studies]]}}{{cite web|author=Dewi, Sita W.|title=FPI members arrested during violent protest|date=3 October 2014|work=The Jakarta Post|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2014/10/03/fpi-members-arrested-during-violent-protest.html}}{{cite web|author=Dewi, Sita W.|title=Muslims declare support for Ahok|date=18 November 2014|work=The Jakarta Post|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2014/11/18/muslims-declare-support-ahok.html}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-37872151|title=Basuki Tjahaja Purnama: Jakarta's governor|publisher=BBC News|date=4 November 2016}} In a 27 September 2016 speech Basuki stated that some citizens were being discouraged from voting for him by politicians citing Verse 51 of the [[Al-Ma'ida|fifth chapter]] of the [[Quran]] out of context for political reasons.{{cite web|url=http://khazanah.republika.co.id/berita/dunia-islam/islam-nusantara/16/10/06/oem6xe313-video-ahok-anda-dibohongi-alquran-surat-almaidah-51-viral-di-medsos|title=Video Ahok: Anda Dibohongi Alquran Surat Al-Maidah 51 Viral di Medsos|author=Sasongko, Agung|date=6 October 2016|work=[[Republika (Indonesian newspaper)|Republika]]}} The verse, [[Surah 5|Quran Surah 5:51]], or QS 5:51, is commonly translated in Indonesian as "Muslims should not appoint the Jews and Christians as their leader." The quran.com translation reads, "O you who have believed, do not take the Jews and the Christians as allies. They are [in fact] allies of one another. And whoever is an ally to them among you—then indeed, he is [one] of them. Indeed, Allah guides not the wrongdoing people."[https://quran.com/5/51 "Surah Al-Ma'idah (5:51)"]. quran.com. Retrieved April 9, 2017. Citizens and pundits reacted to Basuki's statement as [[Quran desecration|an insult to the Quran]], in part because one of the videos of the speech uploaded to the Internet was edited in a way that changed the meaning of his words.La Batu, Safrin (14 December 2016). [http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2016/12/14/accompanying-text-of-ahok-video-not-intended-as-transcript-buni-yani.html "Accompanying text of Ahok video not intended as transcript: Buni Yani"]. ''The Jakarta Post''.[http://www.jakartaglobe.beritasatu.com/news/buni-yani-questioned-again-in-cyber-harrasment-case/ "Buni Yani Questioned Again in Cyber Harassment Case"]. ''[[Jakarta Globe]]''. January 2017.[http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2016/11/23/buni-yani-uploader-of-ahoks-blashpemy-video-named-suspect.html "Buni Yani, uploader of Ahok's blasphemy video, named suspect"]. ''The Jakarta Post''. 23 November 2016La Batu, Saffrin (21 December 2016). [http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2016/12/21/court-rejects-ahok-video-uploaders-pretrial-motion.html "Court rejects Ahok video uploader’s pretrial motion"]. ''The Jakarta Post''. Although Basuki publicly apologized for offending anyone with the remark, the resulting outcry over it led to calls for him to be arrested and prosecuted under laws prohibiting insult to religion. It also sparked protests, led by the hardline group [[Islamic Defenders Front]] (FPI),{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/11/03/asia/jakarta-islamist-governor-protest/index.html|title=Thousands rally in Jakarta over governor's alleged blasphemy|author=McKirdy, Euan|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=5 November 2016}} including one on 2 December 2016,France-Presse, Agence (2 December 2016). [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/dec/02/jakarta-protests-muslims-against-christian-governor-ahok "Jakarta protests: Muslims turn out in force against Christian governor Ahok"]. ''[[The Guardian]]''. which Syaf attended, later calling it "memorable".[[MacDonald, Heidi]] (10 April 2017). [http://www.comicsbeat.com/indonesian-marvel-artist-ardian-syaf-to-be-disciplined-after-controversial-x-men-gold-art-references/ "Indonesian Marvel artist Ardian Syaf to be disciplined after controversial X-Men Gold art references"]. [[Comics Beat]]. Basuki's blasphemy trial began on 13 December.Cochrane, Joe (13 December 2016). [https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/13/world/asia/jakarta-ahok-basuki-indonesia-blasphemy.html?_r=0&mtrref=www.comicsbeat.com&gwh=908F67DFDA1BD6D53F04907ABC7BE94A&gwt=pay "Governor of Jakarta Issues Tearful Denial as Blasphemy Trial Opens in Indonesia"]. ''The New York Times''. [[File:XMenGold1 EasterEggs.png|thumb|The two panels from ''X-Men Gold'' #1 into which Syaf placed references to the [[November 2016 Jakarta protests]]. Note the word "Jewelry", and the numbers "212" and "51" in the detail from Pages 10 and 11 (left), and the "QS:5:51" on [[Colossus (comics)|Colossus]]' shirt in Panel 2 from Page 12 (right).]] On the double-page spread of Pages 10 and 11 of ''X-Men Gold'' #1, in which the Jewish X-Man [[Kitty Pryde]] appeals to a crowd of people for tolerance, Syaf's art places Kitty's head next to the word "Jewelry" on a storefront awning in the background. The number "212", a reference to the 2 December protest, is prominently placed on another store's awning. The number "51" is seen on the baseball cap of one of the people in the crowd, and on the shirt of another, a reference to the Quranic verse 5:51 at the center of the Indonesia protests.Lovett, Jamie (April 8, 2017). [http://comicbook.com/marvel/2017/04/08/marvel-releases-statement-on-controversial-x-men-gold-art/ "Marvel Releases Statement On Controversial X-Men Gold Art"]. [[ComicBook.com]]. The third panel on that spread features a male bystander with a shirt reading "AL M", which may be a reference to Al-Maidah 51, another way to designate the controversial verse.Riseman, Abraham (10 April 2017). [http://www.vulture.com/2017/04/marvels-x-men-were-rocked-by-a-hidden-koranic-message.html "Marvel Was Rocked by a Weird Hidden Koranic Message This Weekend"]. [[Vulture (website)|Vulture]]. In the second panel of Page 12, the X-Man [[Colossus (comics)|Colossus]] wears a shirt prominently displaying the text "QS 5:51". This led to an outcry on social media on Saturday, April 8, three days after the book's publication, by readers who viewed the verse as support of intolerance towards other religions. Syaf was also angrily denounced by Marvel writer [[G. Willow Wilson]], a Muslim herself, who wrote an essay elucidating the verse and warning of the danger of the conservative Indonesian interpretation of it. The Easter eggs also drew negative reaction from Syaf's fellow Indonesian comics creators. The perceived inappropriateness of these messages stemmed from the fact that the ''[[X-Men]]'' storylines have traditionally served as [[allegories]] warning of the dangers of bigotry since their creation in 1963 by [[Stan Lee]] and [[Jack Kirby]] (both of whom are Jewish themselves), and the characters themselves (including the Jewish Kitty Pryde and Catholic [[Nightcrawler (comics)|Nightcrawler]], a former priest) serving as stand-ins for oppressed minority groups.Ching, Albert (April 9, 2017). [http://www.cbr.com/marvel-x-men-gold-artist-controversy/?view=lista "Marvel Responds to X-Men Gold Artist Controversy"]. CBR.com. Regarding the meaning of these details in his artwork, Syaf cautioned against believing what is read on social media, but encouraged readers to buy the issue, as it would become a rare [[collectible]].Johnston, Rich (9 April 2017). [https://www.bleedingcool.com/2017/04/09/ardian-syaf-tries-to-explain-what-happened-yesterday/ "Ardian Syaf Tries To Explain What Happened Yesterday"]. Bleeding Cool. He eventually acknowledged the political nature of the hidden messages, though he denied that they were an expression of intolerance on his part, stating, "I don't hate Jews and Christians... I have a many good friends [among them] too." Syaf, who had previously posted a detail of the pencils for the double page spread on his [[Facebook]] page, removed them following the criticism leveled at him.Tan, Yvette (April 10, 2017). [http://mashable.com/2017/04/10/xmen-indonesia-ahok/#ws8kMSn8Zsq2 "Marvel will punish 'X-men' artist who snuck political references into the latest comic"]. [[Mashable]]. Marvel Comics released the following statement in response to the controversy:
"The mentioned artwork in X-Men Gold #1 was inserted without knowledge behind its reported meanings. These implied references do not reflect the views of the writer, editors or anyone else at Marvel and are in direct opposition of the inclusiveness of Marvel Comics and what the X-Men have stood for since their creation. This artwork will be removed from subsequent printings, digital versions, and trade paperbacks and disciplinary action is being taken."
On April 11, Syaf's contract with Marvel was terminated.Ching, Albert (April 11, 2017). [http://www.cbr.com/marvel-terminates-x-men-gold-artist-ardian-syaf-contract-following-controversy/ "Marvel Terminates X-Men Gold Artist's Contract Following Controversy"]. CBR.com. Marvel's statement is notable for both the swiftness in which Marvel issued it—on a Saturday, hours after the ''X-Men Gold'' art became a point of discussion on social media—and the definitive condemnation of the implied statements in the issue. The writer of the series, [[Marc Guggenheim]], who is himself Jewish, responded to the situation on Saturday by referring readers to Marvel's statement, and [[tweeting]], "The support has been amazing. From fans and pros alike." Syaf reacted to this development by removing his Facebook fan page, and stating on his personal Facebook page, "My career is over now. It's the consequence what I did, and I take it. Please no more mockery, [debate], no more hate. I hope all in peace." Syaf explained that the Quran verse and protest reference that he hid in the comic was intended as a message of "justice" and "love."Ching, Albert (10 October 2017). [http://www.cbr.com/x-men-gold-artist-ardian-syaf-my-career-is-over/ "X-Men Gold Artist Addresses Controversy: ‘My Career is Over Now'"]. CBR.com. The following day, in an interview with the Indonesian newspaper ''[[Jawa Pos]]'', Syaf explained why he thought Marvel did not accept his explanation for including the Easter egg references, saying, "But Marvel is owned by Disney. When Jews are offended, there is no mercy". After making this remark, he reiterated that he was not anti-Semitic or anti-Christian stating that if he was, he would not have worked for a foreign publisher. On his Facebook page, he posted a photo of himself posing with [[Rizieq Shihab]], the founder and leader of the hardline [[Islamic Defenders Front]] (FPI),[https://coconuts.co/jakarta/news/officially-fired-marvel-indonesian-artist-ardian-syaf-officially-says-jews-offended-no-mercy/ "Officially fired by Marvel, Indonesian artist Ardian Syaf says, 'When Jews are offended, there is no mercy'"]. Coconuts Jakarta. 12 April 2017. a former urban [[vigilante]] organization{{cite news | title = Jejak FPI dan Status 'Napi' Rizieq Shihab | author1 = M Andika Putra | author2 = Raja Eben Lumbanrau | publisher = CNN Indonesia | date = 17 January 2017| url = http://www.cnnindonesia.com/nasional/20170117092140-20-186830/jejak-fpi-dan-status-napi-rizieq-shihab/ | language = Indonesian}} turned [[pressure group]] that has been criticized for religious and racial propaganda,{{cite news | title = FPI threatens Chinese Indonesians | author = Sita W. Dewi | newspaper = The Jakarta Post | location = Jakarta | date = September 25, 2014 | url = http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2014/09/25/fpi-threatens-chinese-indonesians.html}} hate crimes, [[discrimination]] against minority groups and [[religious intolerance]],{{cite news |title = Petition calls for disbandment of FPI |author = Arya Dipa | newspaper = The Jakarta Post |date = 18 January 2017 | url = http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2017/01/18/petition-calls-for-disbandment-of-fpi.html}}{{cite news | title = University Students in Manado Take to Streets to Demand FPI Disbandment |newspaper= Jakarta Globe|date=11 February 2017| url = http://jakartaglobe.id/news/university-students-manado-take-streets-demand-fpi-disbandmen/}} and which led the anti-Basuki protests. Syaf then deleted the photo, and blocked his Facebook page to non-friends. The controversy resulted in an April 8 retailer rush demand for the book, which quickly sold out. The issue was still available for re-order through [[Diamond Comic Distributors]], but Diamond was sold out by April 9. On [[eBay]], the standard $4.99 [[USD]] version of the book sold for up to $7.00 while a premiere variant, of which stores were only permitted two copies each, sold for $45 as of April 9, with up to 70 copies posted on the auction website on April 8, compared to 12 the day before.Johnston, Rich (9 April 2017). [https://www.bleedingcool.com/2017/04/09/speculator-corner-x-men-gold-1-ardian-syaf/ "Speculator Corner: X-Men Gold #1 By Ardian Syaf"]. Bleeding Cool. ==Other work== Syaf teaches art to children on weekends. == Published work == === DC === ====Artist==== *''[[Aquaman]]'' #15 *''[[Batgirl]]'' #1 – #13 and #0 *''[[Batman and Robin (comic book)|Batman and Robin]] Annual'' #1 (with various others) *''[[Batman]]: [[Night of the Owls]]'' (with various others) *''[[Birds of Prey (comics)|Birds of Prey]]'' #7 *''[[Brightest Day]]'' #17 – #24 *''[[Catwoman]] Annual'' 1 (with various others) *''[[Green Lantern]]: The End'' (with various others) *''[[Green Lantern]]: Wrath of the First Lantern'' (with various others) *''[[Red Lantern Corps|Red Lanterns]]'' #0 *''[[Superman]]: The Reign of Doomsday'' (with various others) ====Penciller==== *''[[Action Comics]]'' #900 *''[[Batgirl]]'' #1 – #9 *''[[Birds of Prey]]'' #7 *''[[Blackest Night]]: Batman'' #1 – #3 *''Blackest Night: [[Black Lantern Corps]]'' #1 – #3 *''Blackest Night: Rise of the Black Lanterns'' #0 *''[[Brightest Day]]'' #1 – #5, #7, #8, #13, #17, #18 and #24 *''[[Flashpoint (comics)|Flashpoint]]: Emperor Aquaman'' #1 – #3 *''[[Green Lantern]]'' #63 *''[[Green Lantern Corps]]'' #48 – #52 *''[[Justice League of America]]'' #34 *''[[Justice League: Cry for Justice]]'' #1 and #5 *''[[Justice Society of America]]: 80-Page Giant 2010'' (with various others) *''[[Red Hood and the Outlaws]]'' #17 *''[[Superman/Batman]]'' #68 – #70 *''[[The Phantom Stranger]]'' #42 *''[[Titans (comics)|Titans]]'' #23 ====Inker==== *''[[Action Comics]]'' #900 *''[[Green Lantern]]'' #63 ====Colorist==== *''[[Batgirl]]'' #7 – #9 *''[[Blackest Night]]: Rise of the [[Black Lanterns]]'' #0 *''[[Brightest Day]] Aftermath: The Search'' #1 – #3 *''[[Flashpoint (comics)|Flashpoint]]: Emperor Aquaman'' #1 – #3 *''Flashpoint: Reverse Flash'' #1 *''[[Green Lantern]]: Brightest Day'' *''[[Green Lantern Corps]]'' #49 – #52 *''[[Superman/Batman]]'' #68 – #71, #74 *''[[The Phantom Stranger]]'' #42 === Marvel === *''[[X-Men: Manifest Destiny: Nightcrawler]]'' #1 *''[[Captain Britain and MI-13]]'' Vol 1 No's 13 and 14 *''[[Official Handbook of the Marvel Universe]] A To Z Update'' (2010) #1 (with various others) === Other publishers === *''[[Welcome to the Jungle (comics)|Welcome to the Jungle]]'' 2008 hardback graphic novel written by [[science fiction]] and [[fantasy]] author [[Jim Butcher]]. Part of ''[[The Dresden Files]]'' series.Wheeler, Andrew (8 October 2008). [http://www.comicmix.com/2008/10/08/review-the-dresden-files-welcome-to-the-jungle-by-jim-butcher-and-adrian-syaf/ "Review: ‘The Dresden Files: Welcome to the Jungle’ by Jim Butcher and Adrian Syaf"]. [[ComicMix]]. It was nominated for a [[Hugo Award]] in the Best Graphic Novel category.{{cite web | title = 2009 Hugo Award Nominations |publisher = [[Hugo Awards]]| date = 19 March 2009| url = http://www.thehugoawards.org/?p=260 | accessdate =6 November 2013 }} *''[[Storm Front (novel)|Storm Front]], Volume 1: The Gathering Storm''.
