revision.text:
{{short description|Sets of colors that can be combined to make a useful range of colors}} {{About|colors|other uses|Primary Colors (disambiguation){{!}}Primary Colors}}
[[File:CRT phosphors.png|right|thumb|375px|The [[emission spectra]] of the three [[phosphor]]s that define the '''additive primary colors''' of a [[Cathode ray tube|CRT]] color video display. Other electronic color display technologies ([[LCD]], [[Plasma display]], [[OLED]]) have analogous sets of primaries with different emission spectra.]]
A set of '''primary colors''' is, most tangibly, a set of ''real'' [[colorant]]s or colored lights that can be combined in varying amounts to produce a [[gamut]] of colors. This is the essential method used in applications that are intended to elicit the perception of diverse sets of color, e.g. electronic displays, color printing, and paintings. Perceptions associated with a given combination of primary colors are predicted by applying the appropriate mixing model ([[additive mixing|additive]], [[subtractive mixing|subtractive]], additive averaging etc.) that embodies the underlying physics of how light interacts with the media and ultimately the retina.
Primary colors can also be conceptual, either as additive mathematical elements of a [[color space]] or as irreducible phenomenological categories in domains such as psychology and [[Philosophy of color|philosophy]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Beran | first1 = Ondrej | title = The Essence (?) of Color, According to Wittgenstein | journal = From the ALWS archives: A selection of papers from the International Wittgenstein Symposia in Kirchberg am Wechsel | date = 2014 | url = http://wittgensteinrepository.org/agora-alws/article/view/2704/3132 }}</ref> Color-space primaries are precisely defined and empirically rooted in psychophysical color matching experiments which are foundational for understanding [[color vision]]. Primaries of some color spaces are ''complete'' (that is, all visible colors are described in terms of their weighted sums with nonnegative weights) but necessarily ''imaginary''<ref>Bruce MacEvoy. "Do 'Primary' Colors Exist?" ([http://www.handprint.com/HP/WCL/color6.html#imaginary imaginary or imperfect primaries section] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080717034228/http://www.handprint.com/HP/WCL/color6.html#imaginary |date=2008-07-17 }}). ''Handprint''. Accessed 10 August 2007.</ref> (that is, there is no plausible way that those primary colors could be represented physically, or perceived). Describing primary colors from a phenomenological perspective is difficult to do succinctly, but phenomenological accounts, such as the psychological primaries,<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Goldstein | first1 = E. Bruce | last2 = Brockmole | first2 = James | title = Sensation and Perception | date = 2016 | publisher = Cengage Learning | isbn = 978-1-305-88832-6 | page = 206 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=x5d4CgAAQBAJ&pg=PT225&lpg=PT225&dq=%22primary+color%22+phenomenological&source=bl&ots=OEaxtpUt2r&sig=WeVKt8EDe9RkPlZBPEXcEwLFmnI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj6_qmDg9bXAhXrsFQKHXxUDQgQ6AEINTAE#v=onepage&q=%22primary%20color%22%20phenomenological&f=false | language = en }}</ref> have led to practically useful insights.
All sets of real and color-space primaries are ''arbitrary'', in the sense that there is no one set of primaries that can be considered the canonical set. Primary pigments or light sources selected for a given application on the basis of subjective preferences as well as practical factors such as cost, stability, availability etc. Color-space primaries can be subjected to meaningful [[Injective function|one-to-one]] transformations so that the transformed space is still complete and each color is specified with a unique sum.
Elementary art education materials,<ref>{{cite web | title = Color | url = https://www.nga.gov/education/teachers/lessons-activities/elements-of-art/color.html | website = www.nga.gov | accessdate = 10 December 2017 }}</ref> dictionaries,<ref>{{cite web | title = primary color {{! }} Definition of primary color in US English by Oxford Dictionaries|url=http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/us/definition/american_english/primary-color|website=Oxford Dictionaries {{!}} English|accessdate=10 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Definition of PRIMARY COLOR | url = http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/primary%20color | website = www.merriam-webster.com | accessdate = 10 December 2017 | language = en }}</ref> and electronic search engines<ref>{{cite web | title = Wolfram{{! }}Alpha – Primary colors|url=https://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=primary+color&rawformassumption=%7B%22C%22,+%22primary+color%22%7D+-%3E+%7B%22Word%22%7D&rawformassumption=%7B%22DPClash%22,+%22ColorEC%22,+%22primary+color%22%7D+-%3E+%7B%22PrimaryColors%22%7D|website=www.wolframalpha.com|accessdate=10 December 2017|language=en-us}}</ref> often define primary colors effectively as conceptual colors (generally red, yellow, and blue; or red, green, and blue) that can be used to mix "all" other colors and often go further and suggest that these conceptual colors correspond to specific hues and precise wavelengths. Such sources do not present a coherent, consistent definition of primary colors since real primaries cannot be complete.<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Westland | first1 = Stephen | title = Handbook of Visual Display Technology {{! }} Janglin Chen {{!}} Springer|date=2016|publisher=Springer International Publishing|page=162|url=https://rd.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1007/978-3-319-14346-0_11.pdf|accessdate=12 December 2017|language=en}}</ref>
== Additive mixing of light ==
[[File:LCD pixels RGB.jpg|thumb|350px|A photograph of the red, green, and blue elements (subpixels) of an [[Liquid-crystal display|LCD]]. Additive mixing explains how light from these colored elements can be used for photorealistic color image reproduction.]]
The perception elicited by multiple light sources co-stimulating the same area of the retina is additive, i.e., predicted via summing the [[spectral power distribution]]s or tristimulus values of the individual light sources (assuming a color matching context). For example, a purple spotlight on a dark background could be matched with coincident blue and red spotlights that are both dimmer than the purple spotlight. If the intensity of the purple spotlight was doubled it could be matched by doubling the intensities of both the red and blue spotlights that matched the original purple. The principles of additive color mixing are embodied in [[Grassmann's law (optics)|Grassmann's laws]].<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Reinhard | first1 = Erik | last2 = Khan | first2 = Arif | last3 = Akyuz | first3 = Ahmet | last4 = Johnson | first4 = Garrett | title = Color imaging : fundamentals and applications | date = 2008 | publisher = A.K. Peters | location = Wellesley, Mass | isbn = 978-1-56881-344-8 | pages = 364–365 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=suLqBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA364&dq=grassman%27s+laws+additive&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjYz5iD8LPYAhWKxFQKHRrZCfgQ6AEINjAC#v=onepage&q=grassman's%20laws%20additive&f=false | accessdate = 31 December 2017 }}</ref>
Additive mixing of coincident spot lights was applied in the experiments used to derive the [[CIE 1931]] colorspace. The original ''[[monochromatic]]'' primaries of the (arbitrary) wavelengths of 435.8 nm (violet), 546.1 nm (green), and 700 nm (red) were used in this application due to the convenience they afforded to the experimental work.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Fairman | first1 = Hugh S. | last2 = Brill | first2 = Michael H. | last3 = Hemmendinger | first3 = Henry | title = How the CIE 1931 color-matching functions were derived from Wright-Guild data | journal = Color Research & Application | date = February 1997 | volume = 22 | issue = 1 | pages = 11–23 | doi = 10.1002/(SICI)1520-6378(199702)22:1<11::AID-COL4>3.0.CO;2-7 }}</ref>
[[Red]], [[green]], and [[blue]] light are popular primaries for additive color mixing since primary lights with those hues provide a large triangular chromaticity gamut.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Fairchild |first1=Mark |title=Why Is Color - Short Answers - Q: Why are red, blue, and green considered the primary colors? |url=http://rit-mcsl.org/fairchild/WhyIsColor/shortAs.html |website=Color Curiosity Shop |accessdate=4 September 2018}}</ref> Small red, green, and blue elements in electronic displays mix additively from an appropriate viewing distance to synthesize compelling colored images.<ref>{{cite book | title = Light science: physics and the visual arts | author1 = Thomas D. Rossing | author2 = Christopher J. Chiaverina | lastauthoramp = yes | publisher = Birkhäuser | year = 1999 | isbn = 978-0-387-98827-6 | page = 178 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=jpH1_dCT_UcC&pg=PA178&dq=red+green+blue+additive+color+primaries+violet }}</ref>
The exact colors chosen for additive primaries are a technological compromise between the available [[phosphor]]s (including considerations such as cost and power usage) and the need for large chromaticity gamut. The [[Rec. 709|ITU-R BT.709-5]]/[[sRGB]] primaries are typical.
It is important to note that additive mixing provides very poor predictions of color perception outside the color matching context. Well known demonstrations such as [[The dress]] and other examples<ref>{{cite web | last1 = Kircher | first1 = Madison Malone | title = This Baffling Picture of Strawberries Actually Doesn't Contain Any Red Pixels | url = http://nymag.com/selectall/2017/02/strawberries-look-red-without-red-pixels-color-constancy.html | website = Ney York Magazine | accessdate = 21 February 2018 | language = en }}</ref> show how the additive mixing model alone is not sufficient for predicting perceived color in many instances of real images. In general, we cannot completely predict all possible perceived colors from combinations of primary lights in the context of real world images and viewing conditions. The cited examples suggest just how remarkably poor such predictions can be.
== Subtractive mixing of ink layers ==
{{See also|CMYK color model}} [[File:Halftoningcolor.svg|thumb|350px|A magnified representation of small partially overlapping spots of cyan, magenta, yellow, and key (black) [[halftone]]s in [[CMYK]] process printing. Each row represents the pattern of partially overlapping ink "rosettes" so that the patterns would be perceived as blue, green, and red when viewed on white paper from a typical viewing distance. The overlapping ink layers mix subtractively while additive mixing predicts the color appearance from the light reflected from the rosettes and white paper in between them.]]
The [[subtractive color|subtractive]] color mixing model predicts the spectral power distributions of light filtered through overlaid partially absorbing materials on a reflecting or transparent surface. Each layer partially absorbs some wavelengths of light from the illumination spectrum while letting others pass through multiplicatively, resulting in a colored appearance. Overlapping layers of ink in printing mix subtractively over reflecting white paper in this way to generate photorealistic color images. The typical number of inks in such a printing process ranges from 3 to 6 (e.g., [[CMYK]] process, [[hexachrome|Pantone hexachrome]]). In general, using fewer inks as primaries results in more economical printing but using more may result in better color reproduction.
[[Cyan]], [[magenta]], and [[yellow]] are good subtractive primaries in that the spectral power distributions of light reflected from idealized inks can be combined for the largest chromaticity gamuts.<ref>{{cite web | last1 = MacEvoy | first1 = Bruce | title = subtractive color mixing | url = https://www.handprint.com/HP/WCL/color5.html#theorysub | website = Handprint | accessdate = 7 January 2018 }}</ref> An additional ''key'' ink (shorthand for the ''[[key plate|key printing plate]]'' that impressed the artistic detail of an image, usually [[black]]<ref>{{cite book | title = Printing for School and Shop: A Textbook for Printers' Apprentices, Continuation Classes, and for General use in Schools | author = Frank S. Henry | publisher = John Wiley & Sons | year = 1917 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=UAAvAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA292&dq=black+date:0-1923+key-plate+printing+color }}</ref>) is also usually used since it is difficult to mix a dark enough black ink using the other three inks. Before the color names ''cyan'' and ''magenta'' were in common use, these primaries were often known as blue and red, respectively, and their exact color has changed over time with access to new pigments and technologies.<ref>{{cite book | title = General Physics and Its Application to Industry and Everyday Life | author = Ervin Sidney Ferry | publisher = John Wiley & Sons | year = 1921 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=3rYXAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA621&dq=date:0-1923+additive+color+mixing+primary }}</ref>
== Mixing paints in limited palettes ==
[[File:Självporträtt av Anders Zorn 1896.jpg|thumb|upright|200px|A self-portrait by [[Anders Zorn]] clearly showing a four pigment palette of what are thought to be white, [[yellow ochre]], red [[vermilion]] and black pigments.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Nyholm | first1 = Arvid | title = Anders Zorn: The Artist and the Man | journal = Fine Arts Journal | date = 1914 | volume = 31 | issue = 4 | pages = 469 | doi = 10.2307/25587278 }}</ref>]]
The color of light (i.e., the spectral power distribution) reflected from illuminated surfaces coated in paint mixes, slurries of pigment particles, is not well approximated by a subtractive or additive mixing model. Color predictions that incorporate light scattering effects of pigment particles and paint layer thickness require approaches based on the Kubelka–Munk<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Kubelka | first1 = Paul | last2 = Munk | first2 = Franz | title = An article on optics of paint layers | journal = Z. Tech. Phys | date = 1931 | volume = 12 | pages = 593–601 | url = http://www.graphics.cornell.edu/~westin/pubs/kubelka.pdf }}</ref> equations. Even such approaches cannot predict the color of paint mixtures precisely since small variances in particle size distribution, impurity concentrations etc. can be difficult to measure but impart perceptible effects on the way light is reflected from the paint. Artists typically rely on mixing experience and "recipes"<ref>{{cite web | last1 = MacEvoy | first1 = Bruce | title = Mixing Green | url = https://www.handprint.com/HP/WCL/tech34.html | website = Handprint | accessdate = 24 October 2017 }}</ref> to mix desired colors from a small initial set of primaries and do not use mathematical modelling.
There are hundreds of commercially available pigments for visual artists to use and mix (in various media such as oil, watercolor, acrylic, gouache, and pastel). A common approach is to use just a limited palette of primary pigments<ref>{{cite web | last1 = Bruce | first1 = MacEvoy | title = The Artists' "Primaries" | url = https://www.handprint.com/HP/WCL/palette5.html#primaries | website = Handprint | accessdate = 24 October 2017 }}</ref> (often between four and eight) that can be physically mixed to any color that the artist desires in the final work. There is no specific set of pigments that are primary colors, the choice of pigments depends entirely on the artist's subjective preference of subject and style of art as well as material considerations like lightfastness and mixing heuristics. Contemporary classical realists have often advocated that a limited palette of white, red, yellow, and black pigment (often described as the "Zorn palette") is sufficient for compelling work.<ref name="gurney_zorn">{{cite web | last1 = Gurney | title = The Zorn Palette | url = http://gurneyjourney.blogspot.com/2011/07/zorn-palette.html | website = Gurney Journey | accessdate = 27 September 2016 }}</ref>
A [[chromaticity diagram]] can illustrate the gamut of different choices of primaries, for example showing which colors are lost (and gained) if you use RGB for ''subtractive'' color mixing (instead of CMY).<ref>Steven Westland, "subtractive mixing – why not RGB?", October 4, 2009 http://colourware.org/2009/10/04/subtractive-mixing-why-not-rgb/ {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170919234439/http://colourware.org/2009/10/04/subtractive-mixing-why-not-rgb/ |date=2017-09-19 }}</ref>
== Color-space primaries == A contemporary description of the [[color vision]] system provides an understanding of primary colors that is consistent with modern [[color science]]. The human eye normally contains only three types of color photoreceptors, known as long-wavelength (L), medium-wavelength (M), and short-wavelength (S) [[cone cell]]s. These photoreceptor types respond to different degrees across visible electromagnetic spectrum. The S cone response is generally assumed to be negligible at long wavelengths greater than about 560 nm while the L and M cones respond across the entire visible spectrum.<ref name="stockmansharpe2006">{{cite journal | last1 = Stockman | first1 = Andrew | last2 = Sharpe | first2 = Lindsay, T. | title = Physiologically-based colour matching functions | journal = Proceedings of the ISCC/CIE Expert Symposium '06: 75 Years of the CIE Standard Colorimetric Observer | date = 2006 | pages = 13–20 | url = http://cvrl.ucl.ac.uk/people/Stockman/pubs/2006%20Physiological%20CMFs%20SS.pdf }}</ref> The LMS primaries are imaginary since there is no visible wavelength that stimulates only one type of cone (i.e., humans cannot normally see a color that corresponds to pure L, M or S stimulation). The LMS primaries are complete since every visible color can be mapped to a triplet specifying the coordinates in [[LMS color space]].
[[File:Normalized Cone Sensitivities.png|thumb|center|375px|Normalized cone [[spectral sensitivity]] curves]]
The L, M and S response curves (''cone fundamentals'') were deduced from ''color matching functions'' obtained from controlled color matching experiments (e.g., [[CIE 1931]]) where observers matched the color of a surface illuminated by monochromatic light with mixtures of three monochromatic primary lights illuminating a juxtaposed surface. Practical applications generally use a canonical linear transformation of LMS space known as [[CIEXYZ]]. The X, Y, and Z primaries are typically more useful since luminance (Y) is specified separately from a color's chromaticity. Any color space primaries which can be mapped to physiologically relevant LMS primaries by a linear transformation are necessarily either imaginary or incomplete or both. The color-matching context is always three dimensional (since LMS space is three dimensional) but more general ''color appearance'' models like [[CIECAM02]] describe color in six dimensions and can be used to predict how colors appear under different viewing conditions.
Thus for trichromats like humans, we use three (or more) primaries for most general purposes.<ref>{{cite book | title = Colour Design: Theories and Applications | last1 = Best | first1 = Janet | date = 2017 | isbn = 978-0-08-101889-7 | page = 9 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=GfqpDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA9&dq=trichromat+three-primaries+human+tetrachromat&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjx27vZt43XAhUP72MKHat3CpoQ6AEILTAB#v=onepage&q=trichromat%20three-primaries%20human%20tetrachromat&f=false }}</ref> Two primaries would be unable to produce even some of the most common among the named colors. Adding a reasonable choice of third primary can drastically increase the available gamut, while adding a fourth or fifth may increase the gamut but typically not by as much.
Most [[placental mammal]]s other than primates have only two types of color photoreceptor and are therefore [[dichromacy|dichromats]], so it is possible that certain combinations of just two primaries might cover some significant gamut relative to the range of their color perception. Meanwhile, [[birds]] and [[marsupials]] have four color photoreceptors in their eyes, and hence are [[tetrachromats]]. There is one scholarly report of a functional human tetrachromat.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Jordan | first1 = G. | last2 = Deeb | first2 = S. S. | last3 = Bosten | first3 = J. M. | last4 = Mollon | first4 = J. D. | title = The dimensionality of color vision in carriers of anomalous trichromacy | journal = Journal of Vision | date = 20 July 2010 | volume = 10 | issue = 8 | pages = 12–12 | doi = 10.1167/10.8.12 }}</ref>
The presence of photoreceptor cell types in an organism's eyes do not directly imply that they are being used to functionally perceive color. Measuring functional spectral discrimination in non-human animals is challenging due to the difficulty in performing psychophysical experiments on creatures with limited behavioral repertoires who cannot respond using language. Limitations in the discriminative ability of shrimp having twelve distinct color photoreceptors have demonstrated that having more cell types in itself need not always correlate with better functional color vision.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Morrison | first1 = Jessica | title = Mantis shrimp's super colour vision debunked | journal = Nature | date = 23 January 2014 | doi = 10.1038/nature.2014.14578 }}</ref>
== Psychological primaries == [[File:Opponent colors.svg|right|thumb|240px|Approximations within the sRGB gamut to the "aim colors" of the [[Natural Color System]], a model based on the [[opponent process]] theory of color vision.]] {{Main|Opponent process}}
The [[opponent process]] is a color theory that states that the human [[visual system]] interprets information about [[color]] by processing signals from [[cone cell|cones]] and [[rod cell|rods]] in an antagonistic manner. The theory states that every color can be described as a mix along the three axes of red vs. green, blue vs. yellow and white vs. black. The six colors from the pairs might be called "psychological primary colors", because any other color could be described in terms of some combination of these pairs. Although there is a great deal of evidence for opponency in the form of neural mechanisms,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Conway | first1 = Bevil R. | title = Color Vision, Cones, and Color-Coding in the Cortex | journal = The Neuroscientist | date = 12 May 2009 | volume = 15 | issue = 3 | pages = 274–290 | doi = 10.1177/1073858408331369 }}</ref> there is currently no clear mapping of the psychological primaries to neural substrates.<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Cohen | first1 = Jonathan | last2 = editors | first2 = Mohan Matthen, | title = Color ontology and color science | date = 2010 | publisher = MIT Press | location = Cambridge, Massachusetts | isbn = 978-0-262-51375-3 | pages = 159–162 | edition = New | url = https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=-SYTDgAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PA151&dq=%22psychological+primaries%22+colors+irreducible&ots=zsoZ2CD3Fi&sig=Vokd_PDSxhfzjqerMHcJC6W6GRk#v=onepage&q=the%20psychological%20primaries&f=false }}</ref>
The three axes of the psychological primaries were applied by [[Richard S. Hunter]] as the primaries for the colorspace ultimately known as [[CIELAB]]. The [[Natural Color System]] is also directly inspired by the psychological primaries.<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Maffi | first1 = ed. by C.L. Hardin [and] Luisa | title = Color categories in thought and language | date = 1997 | publisher = Cambridge University Press | location = Cambridge | isbn = 978-0-521-49800-5 | pages = 163–192 | edition = 1. publ. | url = https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=ix8l5X5ZBogC&oi=fnd&pg=PA163&dq=%22natural+color+system%22#v=onepage&q=%22natural%20color%20system%22&f=false }}</ref>
== History == There are numerous competing primary colour systems throughout history. Scholars and scientists engaged in debate over which hues best describe the primary color sensations of the eye.<ref>{{cite book | title = Text-book of physiology | volume = 2 | author = [[Edward Albert Sharpey-Schäfer]] | publisher = Y. J. Pentland | year = 1900 | page = 1107 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=fz0uAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA1107&dq=primary+red-green-and-violet+maxwell+sensation }}</ref> [[Thomas Young (scientist)|Thomas Young]] proposed red, green, and violet as the three primary colors, while [[James Clerk Maxwell]] favoured changing violet to blue. [[Hermann von Helmholtz]] proposed "a slightly purplish red, a vegetation-green, slightly yellowish, and an ultramarine-blue" as a trio.<ref>{{cite book | title = A text book of the principles of physics | author = Alfred Daniell | publisher = Macmillan and Co | year = 1904 | page = 575 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=oPQZAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA575&dq=primary+red-green-and-violet+maxwell }}</ref> In modern understanding, human [[cone cell]]s do not correspond precisely to a specific set of primary colors, as each cone type responds to a relatively broad range of wavelengths.
== See also == * [[Color vision]]
== References == {{reflist}}
{{Color topics}} {{Photography}}

{{Advert|date=March 2018}} {{COI|section|date=June 2018}} '''RAW artists''' (RAW:natural born artists) is an international independent arts organization operating in the [[United States]], [[Canada]] and [[Australia]] that supports artists in visual art, music, film, photography, fashion, hair design, makeup artistry, and performing art. The organization promotes starting and independent artists through multi-genre art events as well as through its online network, providing them with resources, the networking experience, professional photos and promotion. As of January 2018, the RAW artists organization has showcased over 100,000 artists and has hosted over 1,000 showcase events == History and growth == RAW was founded in 2009 by its CEO Heidi LuerraTharpe, Melonie (2012) "Meet Eleanor: curator of curious art extravaganzas" Retrieved from theFeedAtlanta website: http://www.thefeednation.org/meet-eleanor-curator-of-curious-art-extravaganzas/Buena, Christy (2010) "''Interview with Heidi Luerra, RAW:Natural Born Artists' Founder''" Retrieved from Disarray Magazine website: http://www.disarraymagazine.com/2010/12/interview-with-heidi-luerra-rawnatural.html
 and now marketing director and web designer Matthew Klahorst in Los Angeles, California. During the organization's first year, showcases were held in five cities throughout Southern California.Groovey (2011) [http://adobeairstream.com/art/interview-with-raw-founder-heidi-luerra/ "Interview with RAW Founder Heidi Luerra"]. Retrieved from Adobe Airstream website By the following year, the organization launched a [[San Francisco]] chapter and planned a nationwide expansion. By 2011, RAW artists was in 20 cities across the country.Breeding, Ashley (2010), [http://articles.coastlinepilot.com/2010-07-22/entertainment/tn-cpt-0723-raw-20100722_1_indie-art-and-music-event-showcases "Cultivating RAW talent"]. Retrieved from Coastline Pilot website''Miami New Times'' (2012) [http://www.miaminewtimes.com/bestof/2012/award/best-arts-collective-3315552/#livefyre "Best Arts Collective RAW:Natural Born Artists"] In 2012, RAW made its first international debut with its [[Brisbane]], QLD Australia chapter.Brook, Lucy (2012) ''Kristen Wehlow – RAW Brisbane''. Retrieved from The Native Press website: {{cite web |url=http://thenative.com.au/kristen-wehlow-raw-brisbane/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-05-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130504090750/http://thenative.com.au/kristen-wehlow-raw-brisbane/ |archivedate=2013-05-04 |df= }}Michaud, Debbie (2012) ''"RAW artist throwdown at Terminal West"'' Retrieved from Creative Loafing website: http://clatl.com/freshloaf/archives/2012/06/29/raw-artist-throwdown-at-terminal-west RAW artists have since branched to more than twelve locations in Australia.Thomas, Anthony (2012) ''Hear Them RAW!'' Retrieved from Moustache Magazine website: http://www.moustachemagazine.com/2012/08/hear-them-raw/ In summer of 2013, RAW artists expanded into Canada with [[Montreal]], QC[http://www.confrontmagazine.com/2013/10/21546/ "RAW: Montreal"]. ''Confront Magazine''. by Michelle Normandeau. and [[Vancouver]], BC chapters. ==Business model== Sales of RAW tickets are enacted by the artists featured, who are expected to purchase tickets from RAW and sell them on. Whilst RAW does not provide any compensation to the artists involved, the artists retain the proceeds from any sales of their work. This business practice has let to criticism from some artists, who have derided RAW as "pay-to-play".{{cite web |last1=Zaragoza |first1=Alex |title=Beef Week: A RAW Deal for Local Artists |url=https://www.voiceofsandiego.org/topics/arts/beef-week-a-raw-deal-for-local-artists/ |publisher=Voice of San Diego |accessdate=26 November 2018}}{{cite web |last1=Gibson |first1=Dan |title=Article About RAW: Natural Born Artists Might Confirm What You Thought About the Organization |url=https://www.tucsonweekly.com/TheRange/archives/2014/03/14/article-about-raw-natural-born-artists-might-confirm-what-you-thought-about-the-organization |publisher=Tucson Weekly |accessdate=26 November 2018}}{{cite web |last1=Hortillosa |first1=Summer Dawn |title=RAW artists, international arts organization, schedules exhibit in Hudson County |url=https://www.nj.com/jjournal-news/index.ssf/2014/02/raw_artists_schedule_a_exhibit.html |publisher=Jersey Journal |accessdate=26 November 2018}} == RAWards == At the end of every season (October), RAW artists hosts an awards show called RAWards. The awards season is a two-month process with an online voting, local semi-final shows with live voting, and lastly, a selection by a panel of judges made up of industry professionals from each field. One winner is chosen from each category (e.g. "RAW Visual Artist of the Year") and the nine winners are honored at a RAWards ceremony and show in Hollywood, CA in January. In 2012, RAW artists hosted two separate awards shows, in the United States and Australia.Egan, Brenna (2012) ''The Indie RAWards: So Not Your Average Awards Show!'' Retrieved from Refinery29 website: http://www.refinery29.com/raw-art-awards-2012 === Previous winners === '''2009''' * Art: Michael Pukac * Music: Roman Alexander and the Robbery * Film: Shelton Films * Fashion: Dane Lenon * Performing Art: Linden Wolbert, Mermaids in Motion * Hair and Makeup: Marc Magpile '''2010''' * Art: Set Fashion: Enrique Ferra * Photography: Melissa Bring * Music: Hey You! * Accessories: Ardent Reverie * Film: Meg Pinsonneault, ''A Lost Love Story'' * Hair: Jaymz Marez * Makeup: Alexander Peuchot * Performing Art: Ooh La La * Natural Born Artist of the Year: Aaron Isaac Joshua '''2011''' * Art: Lawren Alice * Fashion: Mariel Rojo * Photography: Jeff Blucher * Music: Glass Battles * Accessories: The Indra * Hair: Kimmi Le * Makeup: Alan Anderson * Film: Iliya Gegov, ''Nedele'' * Performing Art: Electriq Dance '''2012''' * Art: Gel Jamlang * Fashion: Autumnlin x Heartless Revival * Accessories: Hyper Haute Jewelry * Photography: Eric Honeycutt * Music: Wrings * Hair: Heggy Gonzalez * Makeup: Cris Alex * Film: Lauren Ratcliff, ''Birth of a Wino'' * Performing Art: Jacob Jonas & Jill Wilson '''2012 (AUS)''' * Visual Art: Ellie Anderson * Fashion: Alexander McGuire * Photography: Grace Markham * Music: Brianna Carpenter * Accessories: Luke Maninov * Hair: Valentin Stefanov * Makeup: Alicia Patterson * Film: Jack Webb * Performing Art: Lillian Lace == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *{{Official website|rawartists.org}} [[Category:International artist groups and collectives]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 2009]]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{lead too short|date=June 2018}} {{additional citations|date=August 2018}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox building |name = Shakiragha mausoleum |native_name = {{lang-az|Şakirağa türbəsi}} |image = Shakiragha-Tomb.jpg |caption = |former_names = |building_type = [[Mausoleum]] |architectural_style = [[Architecture ofy Azerbaijan|Architectural school of Absheron]] |structural_system = |address = |location_city = [[File:WP baku siegel.png|22px|]] [[Baku]] |location_country ={{flagicon|Azerbaijan}} [[Azerbaijan]] |location = [[Balaxanı|Balakhany]] |owner = |client = Mirirakhur Shakir Agha ibn-marhum Murtaza |current_tenants = |landlord = | map_type = Azerbaijan | map_relief = | map_size = | map_caption = Location within Azerbaijan |coordinates = {{coord|40.463719|N|49.920087|E}} |start_date = |completion_date = 1427–1428 |demolition_date = |material = |height = |diameter = |other_dimensions = |floor_count = |floor_area = |main_contractor = |architect = |structural_engineer = |services_engineer = |civil_engineer = |other_designers = |quantity_surveyor = |awards = }} '''Shakiragha mausoleum''' ({{lang-az|'''Şakirağa türbəsi'''}}) is a historical monument of the XV century. It is located in [[Balaxanı|Balakhany]] village in the city of [[Baku]] in Azerbaijan.<ref name="sabunchu"/>
==History== Shakiraga mausoleum is located in Balakhani Cemetery and was built in 1427–1428.<ref name="sabunchu">{{cite web|title= Ölkə və yerli əhəmiyyətli Memarlıq və Arxeoloji abidələr|url= http://sabunchu-ih.gov.az/page/120.html|publisher= sabunchu-ih.gov.az|language= az|accessdate=13 March 2018}}</ref> It is also It is six meters from the Haji Shahla mosque which was built in 1385–1386. The information about the monument is limited. The monument was once destroyed by the Soviet as a religious monument.<ref name="gomap"/>
During an excavation in 1976, gold was found at its foundation. At that time, big earthenware pots full of gold were buried in basis of the monuments for their future restoration. The mausoleum was repaired with few percent of the found gold.<ref name="gomap">{{cite web|title= Hacı Şakir türbəsi|url= https://kataloq.gomap.az/az/all-poi/culture/cemetery/8ea7ee12d56611e0ad4900226424597d|publisher= kataloq.gomap.az|language= az|accessdate=13 March 2018}}</ref>
There are two-lined inscription in [[Arabic]] on the [[arch]]-shaped entrance door. Is written in the text:
{{cquote|''"Mirirakhur Shakir Agha ibn-marhum Murtaza, one of the elders of the nation and religion, ordered the construction of this monument. Year 831 (1427–28)"''}} According to another source, Shakiragha mausoleum was erected by [[Ibrahim I of Shirvan|Shirvan Ibrahim]]’s vizier in honor of his son in 1427, and is called a mansion.<ref name="gomap"/>
==Architectural features== The mausoleum consists of hall with a dome and a main arch of the facade with ledge. It is built of white stone, which is characteristic for Absheron architecture.<ref name="gomap"/>
The mausoleum is cross-shaped in the plan. There are several cross-shaped monuments (Khan's Garden pavilion in [[Nardaran]], mausoleum in [[Palace of the Shirvanshahs]] complex and others) by its interior structure in [[Absheron Peninsula|Absheron]]. However, there is no second monument in the shape of cross by its both internal and external structure as Shakiragha mausoleum in Azerbaijan.
The entrance to the mausoleum is the [[Portal (architecture)|portal]] on the north. At internal area of the portal, octagonal prism-shaped niches, which are completed with arrow-shaped arch at both sides, are placed. There are also 8 niches of different sized rectangles inside the mausoleum.
The entrance is from the door, which is finished with a low arrow-shaped arch. The arch on the door is hewed from a whole stone. The surface of the stone is decorated with a plant ornament. There is also another stone placed on arch stone of the entrance, on which two lines of an epic writing is carved. The entrance and the stone with writing are framed with profiled large stone blocks.
==See also== * [[Haji Shahla Mosque]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Buildings and structures completed in the 15th century]] [[Category:Islamic architecture]] [[Category:Mausoleums in Azerbaijan]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Azerbaijan]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Baku]] [[Category:Architecture]]

{{Infobox book series | name = ''Social Register'' | image = File:2018_edition_of_the_Social_Register.png | image_caption = Cover of the 2018 edition of the ''Social Register'' | books = | author = | editors = | title_orig = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = [[United States]] | language = [[English (language)|English]] | discipline = <!-- or |genre= --> | publisher = | pub_date = | english_pub_date = | media_type = | number_of_books = | list_books = | oclc = | preceded by = | followed by = | website = }}
The '''''Social Register''''' is a semi-annual publication in the [[United States]] that indexes the members of [[High society (social class)|high society]]. First published in the 1880s by newspaper columnist [[Louis Keller]], it was later acquired by [[Malcolm Forbes]]. Since 2014 it has been owned by Christopher Wolf.
Long a directory of well-connected, [[old money|patrician]] families from the [[northeast United States]] it has, in recent years, diversified both in the geography and ethnicity of those it lists. At the same time, however, its importance as an arbiter of class has waned.
==History== [[File:Biltmore_Estate.jpg|thumb|The ''Social Register'' was born out of the Gilded Age. Pictured is the Gilded Age mansion, [[Biltmore Estate|Biltmore]], in [[Asheville, North Carolina]].]]
In antebellum [[New York City]], the social elite was still a small enough group that no formal method of tracking individuals was necessary.<ref name="mont">{{cite book|last1=Montgomery|first1=Maureen E.|title=Displaying Women: Spectacles of Leisure in Edith Wharton's New York|date=2016|publisher=Routledge|isbn=1134952864|page=238}}</ref> With the advent of the [[Gilded Age]], however, fashionable ladies began the practice of leaving [[Visiting card|calling cards]] at the homes of other notable women whom they visited; these cards would be cataloged into "visiting lists".<ref name="mont"/><ref name="rr"/> In 1887 Louis Keller, a [[newspaper]] society columnist and [[golf]] promoter, compiled the names of those on the visiting lists of the most prominent New York women into a published volume titled the ''Social Register''.<ref name="lat">{{cite news|last1=Winship|first1=Frederick|title=Social Register Marks 100 Years of Listing Everybody Who's Anybody|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1988-02-11/news/vw-42230_1_social-register|accessdate=May 6, 2018|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=February 11, 1988}}</ref>{{efn|A ''Social Register'', published by Keller for [[Newport, Rhode Island]], preceded the New York edition by one year.<ref name="higley">{{cite book|last1=Higley|first1=Stephen|title=Privilege, Power, and Place: The Geography of the American Upper Class| date=1995|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=0847680215|pages=29-30}}</ref>}} Inclusion in the registry was done under the supervision of an anonymous advisory committee composed of some of those listed.<ref name="lat"/> This first edition of the ''Social Register'' listed more than 5,000 people, most of whom were descended from early American settler families. Joseph Pulitzer was the only [[Jew]] to be listed, and people from [[new money]] were generally not included.<ref name="lat"/> The register, it has been noted, was very much a product of Gilded Age excess.<ref name="higley"/>
By [[World War I]], the ''Social Register'' had expanded into a multi-volume annual which included listings of Society members in 26 U.S. cities.<ref name="lat"/><ref name="rr"/> Following Keller's death in 1924, the ''Social Register'' passed to several of his heirs.<ref name="higley"/>
A 1973 column in ''[[The New York Times]]'' about that year's ''Social Register'' observed that – unlike males listed – the volume did not list the universities attended by females, unless they were students: "The fact that Mazie Cox is a 1967 graduate of [[Smith College|Smith]] is not mentioned, although pains are taken to indicate that she is a member of the Colony Club, the [[Daughters of the Cincinnati]] and the [[Colonial Dames of America]]."<ref name="nyt2">{{cite news|last1=Robinson|first1=Ruth|title='74 Social Register Has Few Surprises|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1973/12/05/archives/74-social-register-has-few-surprises-not-in-new-edition.html|accessdate=May 6, 2018|work=[[New York Times]]|date=December 5, 1973}}</ref> It also noted that married women who chose to retain their [[maiden name]]s would be listed under the surname of their husband regardless.<ref name="nyt2"/>
In 1976, ownership of the ''Social Register'' was acquired by [[Malcolm Forbes]] and, the following year, he re-consolidated the various city books back into a single volume for the whole of the United States.<ref name="lat"/> A study of the 1988 ''Social Register'' found that approximately 10 percent of those listed resided in [[Manhattan]] with the [[Upper East Side]] [[zip code]] of 10021 hosting the greatest concentration of listed persons.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Morin|first1=Richard|title=America’s Social Elite Still Love New York|url=http://www.spokesman.com/stories/1995/aug/06/americas-social-elite-still-love-new-york/|accessdate=May 6, 2018|work=[[Spokesman Review]]|agency=[[Universal Press Syndicate]]|date=August 6, 1995}}</ref>
The Forbes family retained ownership of the ''Social Register'' until 2014, when it was sold to Christopher Wolf, a "longtime, listed member".<ref name="rr"/><ref name="post">{{cite news|last1=Kelly|first1=Keith|title=Forbes sells directory that catalogs Old Money families|url=https://nypost.com/2014/11/01/forbes-sells-directory-that-catalogs-old-money-families/|accessdate=May 6, 2018|work=[[New York Post]]|date=November 1, 2014}}</ref>
===Significance=== Inclusion in the ''Social Register'' has historically been limited to members of polite society, members of the [[American upper class]] and [[The Establishment]], and/or those of "[[old money]]" or [[White Anglo-Saxon Protestant]] (WASP) families, within the ''Social Register'' cities. According to McNamee and Miller: "the acronym WASP... is exemplified by the ''Social Register'', a list of prominent upper-class families first compiled in 1887... There is great continuity across generations among the names included in these volumes."<ref> {{cite book|author1=Stephen J. McNamee|author2=Robert K. Miller|title=The Meritocracy Myth|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-9AUI0CJ5eIC&pg=PA63|year=2004|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|page=63|isbn=9780742510562}}</ref> The cities are [[Newport, Rhode Island]], [[Baltimore]], [[Boston]], [[Chicago]], [[Cleveland]], [[New York City|New York]], [[New Jersey]], [[Philadelphia]],<ref>The Philadelphia volume included [[Wilmington, Delaware]].</ref> [[Pittsburgh]], [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]], [[Providence, Rhode Island|Providence]], [[San Francisco]], [[Seattle]], [[St. Louis]], and [[Washington, D.C.]], as well as ones for "Southern Cities".<ref>examples may be found in [http://digital.library.umsystem.edu/cgi-bin/Ebind2h3/umsl7?seq=2 Page 2 of the 1925 Social Register of St. Louis, Missouri]</ref> In European countries, similar directories for the perceived [[upper class]], such as ''[[Burke's Peerage]]'' and ''[[Burke's Landed Gentry|Landed Gentry]]'' in the [[United Kingdom]], have been published for centuries.
According to the ''[[Robb Report]]'', inclusion in the ''Social Register'' "bespeaks old money, [[Ivy League]], trust funds, privileges of birth, fox hunting, debutante balls, yachting, polo, distinguished forebears, family compounds in the Adirondacks, and a pedigree studded with 19th-century robber barons".<ref name="rr">{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Jack|title=The Membership You Weren’t Allowed to Talk About Is Now Open to New Recruits|url=http://robbreport.com/lifestyle/sports-leisure/the-membership-you-werent-allowed-to-talk-about-is-now-open-to-new-recruits-2771295/|accessdate=May 6, 2018|work=[[Robb Report]]|date=January 8, 2018}}</ref>
However, while inclusion in the ''Social Register'' was once so important for members of Society that, according to [[Brooke Astor]], "if someone wasn't listed, you just didn't know them", by the late 1990s its influence had seriously waned.<ref name="nyt"/> In 2002, novelist [[Tom Wolfe]] said that he no longer heard regular reference to the ''Social Register'' and opined that the "world of social luster has been so overshadowed by celebrities that it doesn’t have any kick anymore".<ref>{{cite news|last1=DiGiacomo|first1=Frank|title=The Forbes Family is Scaling Back Social Register|url=http://observer.com/2002/06/the-forbes-family-is-scaling-back-social-register/|accessdate=May 6, 2018|work=[[New York Observer]]|date=June 17, 2002}}</ref>
==Format== [[File:Social_Register_1920.png|thumb|right|A page from the 1920 edition of the ''Social Register'']] Printed editions of the Social Register have traditionally been bound in black with [[pumpkin (color)|pumpkin]] lettering.<ref name="lat"/> Each edition includes, in epigram, a quote by [[Thomas Jefferson]]:
{{cquote|Let us in education dream of an aristocracy of achievement arising out of a democracy of opportunity.<ref name="rr"/>}}
An individual's listing in the Social Register has generally included contact information, schools attended, and the social and country clubs to which they belong.<ref name="nyt">{{cite news|last1=Allison|first1=Sargent|title=The Social Register: Just a Circle of Friends|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/21/style/the-social-register-just-a-circle-of-friends.html|accessdate=May 6, 2018|work=[[New York Times]]|date=December 21, 1997}}</ref> Because many of the institutions cited are done so repeatedly, an extensive system of abbreviations is used; for instance "P" stands for [[Princeton University]] while "BtP" represents the Bath and Tennis Club of [[Palm Beach, Florida]].<ref name="nyt"/>
==Inclusion and exclusion==
===Inclusion=== Wealth or fame has, traditionally, been insufficient for inclusion in the ''Social Register''; [[Kim Kardashian]] and [[Gloria Vanderbilt]] were never listed and [[Donald Trump]], prior to his election as President of the United States, was also not included.<ref name="post"/><ref name="chicago"/> A 1985 article reported that "enrollees need plenty of green (money), blue (blood), and lily white".<ref name="chicago">{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Martha|title=Cleaning House At Social Register -- High Society Can`t Pass (blood)|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1985-02-08/features/8501080213_1_social-register-letters-names|accessdate=May 6, 2018|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|agency=Scripps-Howard News Service|date=February 8, 1985}}</ref>
Listing in the ''Social Register'' has typically been through birth; children born to a person listed in the ''Social Register'' are themselves added. Persons have also been permitted to apply for inclusion in the Social Register. Such applications require letters of sponsorship from five persons already listed, followed by vetting from the advisory committee. A spokesman for the ''Social Register'''s then 25-member advisory committee, in 1997, described the criteria by which a person might be added to the directory.<ref name="nyt"/> The committee, he said, asked themselves "would one want to have dinner with this person on a regular basis"?<ref name="nyt"/>
The [[President of the United States]] and [[Vice-President of the United States]] are, by custom, always added.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Widdicombe|first1=Lizzie|title=Original|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2012/03/26/original|accessdate=May 6, 2018|work=[[New Yorker (magazine)|New Yorker]]|date=March 26, 2012}}</ref>
===Exclusion=== Reasons for removal from the ''Social Register'' have traditionally been opaque.<ref name="mills">{{cite book|last1=Mills|first1=C. Wright|title=The Power Elite|date=1956|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|pages=55-57, 72, 74, 80}}</ref> In the early 20th century, historian [[Dixon Wecter]] observed that those excluded tended to be persons unfavorably reported upon in the press and that, as long as one's private life "keeps out of the [newspaper's] columns" the risk of exclusion was low.<ref>{{cite book|author=C. Wright Mills|title=The Power Elite|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J1ISDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA56|year=2000|page=56}}</ref>
A ''Social Register'' spokesman reported, in 1985, that elderly persons who failed to remit the questionnaire sent to listed persons by the register for eleven consecutive years were removed. In addition, someone who marries a person who is not, themselves, listed in the ''Social Register'' is dropped.<ref>Martha Smith, "Cleaning House At Social Register -- High Society Can`t Pass (blood)' ''Providence Journal'' February 08, 1985</ref>
As of 1988, about 35,000 individuals were included in the ''Social Register''.<ref name="lat"/> By 2014, this number was reported to be approximately 25,000.<ref name="rr"/>
==In popular culture== * The 1934 film ''[[Social Register (film)|Social Register]]'' presented a fictitious look at the lives of persons on the ''Social Register''.
==See also== * [[Debrett's]]
==Notes== {{notelist}}
==References== {{reflist}} ==Primary sources== * [https://ia601406.us.archive.org/25/items/socialregisterl00usgoog/socialregisterl00usgoog.pdf ''Social Register Locater 1916''], an index showing in which local edition each listed person could be found * [https://archive.org/search.php?query=%22social%20register%20%22 35 Social Registers from major US cities early 20th century; online free] * ''The Social Register of Canada,'' volume I (1958), and subsequent volumes 2 (1959), and 3 (1961), The Social Register of Canada Association. Montreal, Canada
{{italic title}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Social Register}} [[Category:1887 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:Social institutions]] [[Category:Social class in the United States]] [[Category:Books by type]] [[Category:Upper class culture]]

page.title: Spill: Scenes of Black Feminist Fugitivity

revision.text:
{{italics title}} == ''Spill: Scenes of Black Feminist Fugitivity'' == ''Spill'' is a 2017 book of prose and poetry by Alexis Pauline Gumbs.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.dukeupress.edu/spill|title=Spill|work=Duke University Press|access-date=2018-03-22|language=en-US}}</ref> It is a labor of love, and an experimental and poetic work of literary criticism based on the work of [[Hortense Spillers]] and the literary archive of freedom seeking black women.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.alexispauline.com/brillianceremastered/bio/|title=Bio|last=Gumbs|first=Alexis Pauline|date=22 Mar 2018|website=alexispauline.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=22 Mar 2018}}</ref> Containing the first syllable of Spillers’ last name, it is an ode to Hortense, the individual, as much as it nurtures–and is nurtured by–black femme folk across vast spatiotemporal locations. The subtitle, "''Scenes of Black Feminist Fugitivity"'' nods to [[Saidiya Hartman]]’s Scenes of Subjection: Terror, Slavery, and Self-making in Nineteenth Century America.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://global.oup.com/academic/product/scenes-of-subjection-9780195089844?cc=us&lang=en&|title=Scenes of Subjection: Terror, Slavery, and Self-Making in Nineteenth-Century America|date=1997-09-04|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780195089844|series=Race and American Culture|location=Oxford, New York}}</ref> The work pays homage to not just Saidiya, and not just Hortense, in fact not any singular “I” understood within a Cartesian ''"[[Cogito ergo sum]]''" which would subordinate the collective to the individual. “When I turned these phrases, doors opened and everyone came through,” Gumbs writes of her engagement with Spillers’ work, “all the black women writers Spillers wrote about and didn’t write about. All the characters those black women writers acknowledged and ignored.”<ref name=":0" /> Gumbs converses with black study and black womanhood: past, present, and future.
== Interventions == By introducing the concept of writing "with" black women as opposed to writing "about" or "to" an audience, ''Spill'' is testament to the fact that an academic book can be written whilst citing one black woman directly in the text. This is a key intervention, performance, and achievement. Every in-text citation references Spillers’s ''Black, White, and in Color: Essays on American Literature and Culture.''<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://press.uchicago.edu/ucp/books/book/chicago/B/bo3624045.html|title=Black, White, and in Color}}</ref> After ''Spill’''s endnotes, Gumbs lists a bibliography of “Indirect References and Suggested Reading,” composed entirely of women of color authors––most of whom are black. If nothing else, the following message is clear: read and cite black women. By engaging Spillers through poetry, an omnitemporal, omnipresent black womanhood emerges on the page.
== Reception == Hortense Spillers stated in public conversation: "Nobody else is like Alexis. ...There is really nothing else like this book in my experience as a student, a scholar, a reader, a teacher. The kind of conversation that the text is setting up between poetry and prose, and between a poetic posture and a scholarly posture, I don't think I've ever seen that."<ref>{{Citation|last=John Hope Franklin Center at Duke University|title=Left of Black with Hortense Spillers and Alexis Pauline Gumbs|date=2017-03-22|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ui-EZQ1BTfE&t=1989s|accessdate=2018-03-22}}</ref>
The La Review of books calls it "''a 'poetilitical praxis,' an unflinching look at what pain has wrought and what fruit might yet be born.''"<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://lareviewofbooks.org/article/we-stay-in-love-with-our-freedom-a-conversation-with-alexis-pauline-gumbs/#!|title=We Stay in Love with Our Freedom: A Conversation with Alexis Pauline Gumbs - Los Angeles Review of Books|work=Los Angeles Review of Books|access-date=2018-03-22|language=en-US}}</ref>
''Spill'' was nominee in the '''29th [[Lambda Literary Awards]],''' held on June 12, 2017 in the category of LGBTQ Non-Fiction.
The book was also reviewed by [[Bitch (magazine)]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bitchmedia.org/article/spill-scenes-black-feminist-fugitivity/alexis-pauline-gumbs|title=“Spill” Maps a Future In Which Black Women Inherit the Universe|work=Bitch Media|access-date=2018-03-22|language=en}}</ref>
== References == <!-- Inline citations added to your article will automatically display here. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WP:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. --> {{reflist}}
[[Category:2017 anthologies]] [[Category:Feminist literature]]
